Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having played this game a long time ago, I was unimpressed. Since then there has been a significant graphical update (and a sale) which pushed me to buy it, and I do not regret it. Keep in mind, though that this is an early game, so there are still some unimplemented 'core' features.+ A real-time roguelike with engaging first-person combat. Very enjoyable combat.+ I do like that the levels have their own styles, rather than being the same shape with different art.+ The stats have a very definite impact on your gameplay.- I don't think there's enough variety in the random level generation to make it worth playing through more than once. Especially the damned sewer levels. - I don't think Delver (right now) has much replay value. I found just maxxing your Health to the exclusion of all other stats is really the most effective strategy. I did that, beat the boss, and practically waltzed back up to the surface, orb in hand, without a scratch. What did I have to show for it? Nothing except money. Exactly the same thing I would have had if I died to the end boss.- I never bought anything from the shop anyway. There's plenty of free loot in the dungeon, better than what you can buy. I found no reason to collect nor spend money. Maybe shops in the dungeon would help because I often need a specific item, like a potion or wand. I'm a big fan of the wands*. Please put in more kinds of wand.*Totally not guns.~ What if beating the Lich unlocked lower levels?~ What if lower levels unlocked more items from the shop/more shops?It's a fun game, which I enjoyed more than I expected to, but it is not done yet! Very playable, but feels empty and pointless once you've beat the Lich once. I was kinda hoping for a whole new dungeon to open up, but it's early days.

Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review

Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very enjoyable at this point, You start at a camp and progress downwards in randomly generated levels ranging in appearance with stone, lava, and jungle themes being present as you progress. Large variety of weapons and easy to use inventory. Anyone looking for a great time killer def check this out, oh also I enjoy the fact it saves the game but when you die your dead and need to start all the way over. also you can buy stuff from npc's in the camp.

Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bought this for sale 66% off at $2.50ish during a steam sale. I think this was money well spent for the hour or so of enjoyment I got out of the game. Even buying it at full price, it would have paid for itself.The combat is pretty basic but it works well for the slow paced combat. The visuals are very reminiscent of Minecraft along with all the controls. The inventory system works well for allowing you to collect loot along your trip down the dungeon and the randomized potions give a little risk to using them each time you restart, which is frustrating but in a good way.As for faults, the level/stat system is a little broken as you only need to put points into health for the first five levels and defense the rest to become relatively hard to kill. Ranged combat versus flying enemies, which is when it's needed, is a fools game unless you're using a lightning wand (almost hit scan), as projectiles have travel time and flying enemies juke around way too much to predict their movements. I just found myself running up under them and stabbing upward for a sure hit.Finally, while I died the first time down the dungeon due to trying to figure out the system, I beat the game on the second try. I received a slash screen of text and then the game treated me like I had died. I'm pretty much not going down a third time until there are further updates, but as I said at the start, I got my money's worth already and I recommend a purchase, especially if it's on sale again.TL;DR - It's an enjoyable game but has it's issues. Worth a buy, especially if it's on sale.

Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having played this game a long time ago, I was unimpressed. Since then there has been a significant graphical update (and a sale) which pushed me to buy it, and I do not regret it. Keep in mind, though that this is an early game, so there are still some unimplemented 'core' features.+ A real-time roguelike with engaging first-person combat. Very enjoyable combat.+ I do like that the levels have their own styles, rather than being the same shape with different art.+ The stats have a very definite impact on your gameplay.- I don't think there's enough variety in the random level generation to make it worth playing through more than once. Especially the damned sewer levels. - I don't think Delver (right now) has much replay value. I found just maxxing your Health to the exclusion of all other stats is really the most effective strategy. I did that, beat the boss, and practically waltzed back up to the surface, orb in hand, without a scratch. What did I have to show for it? Nothing except money. Exactly the same thing I would have had if I died to the end boss.- I never bought anything from the shop anyway. There's plenty of free loot in the dungeon, better than what you can buy. I found no reason to collect nor spend money. Maybe shops in the dungeon would help because I often need a specific item, like a potion or wand. I'm a big fan of the wands*. Please put in more kinds of wand.*Totally not guns.~ What if beating the Lich unlocked lower levels?~ What if lower levels unlocked more items from the shop/more shops?It's a fun game, which I enjoyed more than I expected to, but it is not done yet! Very playable, but feels empty and pointless once you've beat the Lich once. I was kinda hoping for a whole new dungeon to open up, but it's early days.

Posted: January 2, 2014

Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								It took only a few minutes for me to fall in love with this game.  There is a quality to it that is somewhat difficult to put your finger on at first, but I would be describe the environment as being almost perfect.While this game is a roguelike (yes, yes someone is always going to complain about how this isn't a pure roguelike) when I first loaded the game I felt flashes of playing the Secret of Mana for the first time.  A combination of the music, the art, the very simple UI, and carefully timed, if simple, combat hit me right in the nostalgia.Currently it is in beta, and there is much content I have yet to explore, but there is only one shortcoming I see so far.  I want multiplayer.  I don't care what it takes, quadruple the difficulty per person, but I would absolutely love to have multiplayer.  I'll pay for multiplayer DLC, whatevs.I highly recommend this game.

Posted: January 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just started delving into Delver and the game is simply fantastic. Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Incredibly hard, crazy rogue-like, with a variety of terrain, weapons, and other items. A fresh take on the rogue-like genre, being in first person. Started out as a post on tigsource, updating almost every day. Now on steam early-access, with sparse updates.Pros:•Of all the rogue-likes I've played, this one is probably the most achievable whilst still being difficult.•Variety of weapons and other helpful items that you can dual wield, with an alright variety of monsters and terrain. •A nice atmosphere, without a simple story to discover through notes on the ground.•A hack 'n' slash, but very well done in first person mode.•Simple, but very replayable.Cons:•Horrible, horrible, textures, read below for info on how to get past that.•Somewhat disappointing boss, which can be good for those who aren't up to the challenge. Just don't get hit, which is pretty easy.•Once you kill the boss, you have to work your way back up the 8 floors you just traveled, which can be somewhat boring.8/10, but if you want to enjoy it, get the official texture pack that has the original textures from the game when it was on tigsource, which are far better than this crunchy-pixel crap. The texture pack is updated with every update, and has optional "mods" that slightly improve generation.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								A solid rogue-like with an appropriate amount of content for a Beta. A solid variety of weaponry and enemies allow for several hours of fun, afterwards it gets rather repetitive. But hopefully more content will be added soon after this long hiatus.Immediately you're cast in the dungeon and it's up to you to learn, and until you do learn, it's trial and error which will lead to death. Once finished, the game doesn't offer any much more to do.The combat is fun, though you have to be aware of the attack speed of each weapon, as well as their damage output and the enemy you're up against. All potions are unknown until drunk, once or several times. This adds an additional risk because you might end up commiting suicide.The artstyle is enjoyable as is the exploration of randomly generated dungeons.>I'd give it a 6.5/10, it's a solid pickup on sale, fully priced only if they add more>Pros: random dungeons, combat is okay, risky potions increase difficulty, stats matter, quickly load your saves>Cons: you can only change options from the Main Menu, you'll find it difficult to get used to how inventory and items work, prone to using items accidentally(ie. pressing the wrong hotbar key will eat the item instantly rather than selecting it)

Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver, the Early Access Rogue-Like RPG.I saw this game and it sparked my interest because it reminded me a little of Might and Magic World of Xeen. Then upon realizing it was a first person rogue-like game and not the typical side scrolling one, I had to get it.The game looks and play beautifully, I changed the key bindings a little more to my tastes but it probably won't bother most on its default settings. On the games website you can buy a HD Sphax PureBD pack (You might recognize the name from the popular Minecraft Texture pack) for $4.90 (2.90€).  The game should be able to run on any computer than can use Steam, due to the simplistic graphics and the slider in the menu. As far as the Rogue aspect of the game, it does it a little differently than say, Rogue Leacy. In that game, you only get the gold from each run to spend as you have to spend it all to enter the castle. But in Delver, you keep all of your gold from each run, but lose any equipment that you got. But once you buy something, you always have it, which is nice. You level up in the dungeon and have a series of classic RPG stats that you can increase, but Health should always be your number 1 priority when leveling as it was the only one that had a major difference to difficulty/gameplay. I got lucky on my longest run and found a warhammer with long reach and high damage. The wands you find will be very useful and they are the only way to get passed something that can happen in the game. Speed is probably the least useful stat in the game especially when matched against Health. I'd like to see a little more depth in the stats.I really didn't notice any bugs that stopped my progress in the game and I could honestly see this game, in its current phase of development, packaged as a full game, I would certainly buy it again. 10/10 and good on the Devs.

Early Access Review
								Delver is extremely charming.  It's a nice, simple dungeon crawler that you can have a cup of tea and play, or pick up and play whenever you want.  There is a mobile version as well, and I'm sure it works very well as that too.  It is /very/ simple, but it is because of that that it is very reminiscent of earlier dungeon crawling titles.  I think this is a fantastic game for beginners of the genre and even after you've spent some time with it, it never really loses its luster.  You may grow disinterested after you've played for a few hours, but with mod support and stuff you can really revive the dead horse if you want -  That said it's always really cheap and it is genuine fun for a few hours.  Try it out atleast. :)

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								A solid rogue-like with an appropriate amount of content for a Beta. A solid variety of weaponry and enemies allow for several hours of fun, afterwards it gets rather repetitive. But hopefully more content will be added soon after this long hiatus.Immediately you're cast in the dungeon and it's up to you to learn, and until you do learn, it's trial and error which will lead to death. Once finished, the game doesn't offer any much more to do.The combat is fun, though you have to be aware of the attack speed of each weapon, as well as their damage output and the enemy you're up against. All potions are unknown until drunk, once or several times. This adds an additional risk because you might end up commiting suicide.The artstyle is enjoyable as is the exploration of randomly generated dungeons.>I'd give it a 6.5/10, it's a solid pickup on sale, fully priced only if they add more>Pros: random dungeons, combat is okay, risky potions increase difficulty, stats matter, quickly load your saves>Cons: you can only change options from the Main Menu, you'll find it difficult to get used to how inventory and items work, prone to using items accidentally(ie. pressing the wrong hotbar key will eat the item instantly rather than selecting it)

								Despite the fact it says I have played under 2 hours of Delver, I have actually played at least 12 hours of this game, if not significantly more, back when it was in an earlier state. This game is highly enjoyable and has a certain something that just makes you want to play it more and maybe win this time. The game is still improving and is not finished, but I can recommend it in its current state. My only issue with the game is the shop system. Currently you can buy items from it using gold you obtain from enemies. At the moment, there is an item called "Skill in a Jar" that levels you up and is fairly cheap. If you get enough gold, you can level yourself up an absurd amount of times and become so overpowered that the game is no fun. However, as long as you avoid the shop, you should have a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								A pretty casual roguelike experience. As of this post, I played it a few times and quickly made it far; only dying to either burst (Didn't get enough health or armor), or my own stupidity. It's very short, which I suppose is a good thing for a game like this. It's easy, but you still can't face-check anything until you get lucky enough with weapons, armor, and stock piles of food / potions. It does get easier as the game goes on, which is a bad and good thing. The stronger you get, the less trouble you have and are capable of dealing with most creatures. But at the same time, before you get to that stage you struggle and have to back-peddle swing many monsters to survive. You do get a lot of wands I have noticed, which trivializes a lot of encounters; which should be their purpose. But the purpose is way too strong when you get a wand drop every other kill. And the mages almost always drop them, even if they are absolute crap -- it's a ranged weapon and you take 0 damage from back-peddling and killing the enemy.Stats are not very clear on what they do besides Attack, Speed, and Health. It's obvious you deal more damage with Attack, move faster when you up speed, and gain more health everytime you level it up. Agility was very vague on what it did, and I still don't feel the effects. The same goes for defense and magic. They feel either too weak to actually present themselves as useful, or are just not straight forward enough.I would recommend this game on sale. It's a decent time waster for a few hours, but it has very little to give after you play through it just a few times.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is an interesting game. It's rather basic at the moment, being early access, but for eight dollars, the amount of content and effort that the game has is really impressive, and it feels very focused in its design. I can see the reason people compare it to Ultima Underworld, since much of the game's gameplay and style are clearly very inspired by it - the first one in particular, I mean. While the combat focus is very fun and the graphical style is really appealing, I actually consider the level design and generation to be the highlight here: I don't know whether it's due to working with a 3D space or whether it's simply the sheer amount of rooms and halls and things that the team have made, but in the handful of runs I've played so far, they've all felt similar, but all memorably unique thanks to how everything is built. It's a roguelike capable of creating really cool vistas, structures and views, while also making those distinct in gameplay terms as well (the dungeon is inhabited and has lots of humans and recent structures, the caves are very jagged with lots of nooks, the sewers are a mixture of open yet linear due to multiple heights, etc), and that's something to be applauded.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								A fairly short FPS roguelike with a Minecraft feel to the graphics and the terrain, as well as the inventory, minus weapon/armor durability, your equipment is indestructible. Except for magic wands/scrolls, which have limited charges but can be very useful.There are also several different colored potions which effects are randomized each playthrough, most of them are helpful, while one of them is poison, so be careful.Then you got your EXP system and leveling up system where you can choose between several stats, I just usually get health every level when I can, you're gonna need it.The general goal is to go down several floors of dungeons, always having the same tileset/theme but a different layout each playthrough, and get the treasure, and then traverse all the way back to camp from where you started as angry monsters chase you after stealing their treasure.A decent enough roguelike, it was fun and lasted about 2 hours so far, going through the game twice. Could use more variety and maybe achievements in the future.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Recommended but there's nothing new here. If it ever gets out of 'Early Access' I suspect it will be solid. The biggest appeal for me was the art style. The usual randomly generated levels, items and whatnot are all here. I finished the game but it seemed like it didn't matter how I was playing, it was all up to the numbers and being lucky. Maybe the game is intended for grinding, like a traditional RPG, but I ended up racing down as fast as I could to kill the boss, then snagging the orb and racing back to the surface. Fighting everything didn't really get me anywhere, especially when one little bump can knock you into a pit and that infamous "permadeath" everyone seems to love puts you back at square one. Maybe a quick tutorial or in-game guide would have helped me since it seems like there are also a lot of useless items to pick up in the game as well. As far as I could tell you can't sell anything at the shops, so why can I pick up cups and bowls? I dropped a book once that killed me, so maybe that's something. Maybe they're for a future update or maybe I didn't dive deep enough into the game. Either way I finished it, so it doesn't really matter at this point.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								A while ago I played this game for a very short amount of time (about 20 min) and could carely make it past the first cave room. I got frustrated and put this game down only to forget about it and leave it uninstalled in my library for qutie some time until I decided to try again. This experience was much different. For those of you who don't know anything about this game, it is a dungeon crawler roguelike first person rpg with a game play that I like to relate to capture the flag. Once you enter the dungeon, you cannot leave until you recover the red orb about 7 floors down and with each level you go down (randomly generated levels of course), the enemy population and difficulty along with the number of hazards increases. Once you obtain the orb, the whole dungeon goes bat♥♥♥♥♥♥and you have to race to the top. So essentially you must play through each floor except the last floor twice and you will progress further with each playthrough. I cannot express how satisfying it is to obtain a new weapon or level up in a tough situation and every second of this game is worth the price. I highly recommend this to anyone who loves rpgs, dungeon crawlers, roguelike first person, and consider it a must have if you enjoy all of the above.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Simple gameplay, fun variety of weapons / spells / potions, lots of replay value.  The game is just *fun*!  It manages to feel like a rogulike, despite the first-person approach, and offers a pretty harsh level of difficulty -- especially the endgame.  It's definitely a "light" roguelike, however.  So, if you're looking for the depth of something like NetHack as an FPS, look elsewhere.  If you're looking for an enjoyable diversion that still offers a challenge, this game is great!The aesthetics are fantastic and create a real sense of charm that sucks you in.  It's one of those "Just...one more time," types of titles.  Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								I firest heard of this game on the BDCraft Sphax Minecraft page.  (That's the texture pack I use on Minecraft because it looks incredible.)  They have a texture pack for this game.So, I thought it sounded cool, and played it, and it is the Dungeon Master "realtime" thing I wanted.  And with the BDCraft texture pack (yes, I paid for that too, because it looks amazing) it just plain looks AMAZING.  See those guys around the campfire?  Yeah, they look like they're from... something else with better graphics (:  Not real, just, you know. Awesome.Anyway this plays like a roguelikelike 3d dungeon crawler should.  You find items, they are sometimes great, you trip traps, you get bit by zombies and you lose life, and you have no food so you die.  You go again and this time you get eaten by a bat.  Then you try again and while trying to reach annoy-o-wizard with your sword, leaving those precious staves with long reach spells in your toolbelt, your head goes 'splode.  It's great and I think I will be playing a TON of this game.Non-Windows people - the bdcraft .exe is just a zip file, use unzip and stick the 'asset' folder in your game dir.  Then "awesome!" ensues.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game truly is amazing. It brings a true feeling of dungeon crawling. Do not be fooled by the pixelated graphics, the game looks stunning. The combination of sprites across the areas make for gorgeous scenery. The enemy sprites are easy to identify and well made. The soundtrack gives a nice feel of adventure. The music remains noted in its glory, but does no distract you from gameplay. The items available are plentiful and well made. The combat is simple enough to adapt to quickly, but still poses some danger when performing it. The game relies heavily on exploration. Notes found in the beginning town give basic instructions to gameplay and an extremely brief lore description that strangely leaves you wanting more, despite being shorter than a paragraph. Not in a long time have I played a game like this, capable of delievering a real feeling of adventure, as well as giving satisfying emotions when discovering new loot. I would recommend this game to any dungeon crawler lover, or someone who simply enjoys a well made adventure game. The fact that I say this now and the game is only in beta truly blows my mind.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								First impressions:The art style is fantastic, and the game is very easy to pick up and start playing immediately. The audio (sound effects, music, etc.) is done very well and sounds great. Controls are responsive, and the game feels very well optimized (no lag in any areas). My favorite aspect of the game is definetly the animations. The death animations are extremely well done and make me smile every time I get a kill.After ~4 hours gameplay:Definitely one of the best rogue-like games I've played. The game just excels on so many levels. From my understanding, the goal of the game is to make it to the bottom level of the dungeon, retrieve an item, and make your way back topside to exit the dungeon. Each level has a set of stairs leading deeper into the dungeon, and each level down gets increasingly diffucult. The first few levels are easy; the real challenge starts to come around the ruins level - the farthest I have gotten in my playthroughs. This deep down, new obstacles start to appear that really display the depth of the game. Some of these include platforms that fall after being walked on, pillars that drop down to crush you, and others. There are also many more enemies tightly packed together compared to the early levels. The levels are randomly generated, with a mix of some prefab areas and it works well.I would definitely recommend supporting the developers and picking up this game in early access. I came across the game completely by accident while prowling the creative section of twitch.tv, and the art developer (Joshua) is friendly and responsive. Well worth the cheap price.

								Sure, it's a rogue-y dungeon crawler, but it never feels like you're DOING anything besides dying and trying again. There needs to be a reason your new character went in and died. Saving gold so you can buy something ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for somebodies run is pointless. I once saved 300+ gold up and bought a sword at the beginning before even starting the dungeon. I then immediatly found a better weapon. There needs to be upgrades that stay between characters or SOMETHING. The game feels pointless and unfinished in it's current state.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very good game, the combat is good. It is pretty easy for the most part on the way in, it is getting out that is the hardest part. Now it can lag a bit when you maximize the screen or fullscreen it, so warning you there. However, a good, scratch that great game overall. Can't wait till the next updates come. We definitely need different dungeons, a difficulty system, more exploration around the upper world (as well as a key that will be given to the player if he deals with a challenge of some kind to get into the other dungeons, such as a guardian, a riddle, a puzzle, something) a better variety of enemies, and a hardcore adventurer option just a few examples of some changes to make it better.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is honestly one of the best rouge-likes ive ever played. Ive played through this game a ton of times and still havent beaten it. in spite of that, it still manages to keep its charm and not give the player (or at least me) any frustration. i feel like this is because of the games fairness, meaning, that each death feels justified in its own way. another good aspect of this game is its 3D environment. putting you into the action in first person has to be the best idea ive seen so far since ive never seen that in a rouge-like before. The 16-bit enemies and environment add a classic feeling to the experience almost as though the game was once in a fourth directional dungeon crawler like "Link to The Past". The randomized floors just add a bit more of anticipation to each floor. each enemy is unique in its own while still keeping a theme throughout the game. overall it is just an enjoyable experience and i always look forward to each gameplay and that is why i recommend this game to any interested. PLEASE DON'T BE HESITANT TO BUY THIS GAME.

								The idea of a first person rogue-like is a simple one with very few competent examples.Delver is not a competent example.Yes it works, but it's so content malnourished I'm pretty sure I finished it within an hour and found no additional goals.Combat is basic as all hell, with the only spell being "wands" that have limited uses, all shoot generic bolts of various degrees of uselessness and weigh your limited inventory down like nobodies business.Avoid this game until it's content gets improved, or unless you can pick it up for 50 cents.

number of helpful: 16 of 31 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								While the game seems interesting as a minecraft looking roguelike dungeon crawler, the gameplay just isn't there.  Combat is simplistic, the dungeons are relatively boring and fairly linear (with side paths branching to dead ends), and overall it just feels very repetitious with no payoff.  Add to that a lack of most options (Just resume and quit from the escape menu in game) and a major lack of updates and you get an unfinished game that doesn't look to be ever completed.  To put it in perspective, this game has been around since 2013 with the last update coming almost a year ago and is still labeled as a beta in early access.  Much larger (and better) games have joined and left early access than this and it's a shame since I could imagine this game fleshing out into something akin to fun.  Unless this game gets a much needed update/expansion/revision, save your money and get something like Legend of Grimrock.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is impressive, so far.Do you like challenge? Delver has it. It's deceptively simple; three equipment selections with apparently-linear upgrading; you only choose whether to equip heavier armor at a loss of speed. Amulets and rings? Straightforward. Weapons? Same deal, though they can be enchanted for bonus elemental damage. All in all it seems like the sort of game you can fully-understand in 30 minutes or less.And then, on your second or third play(or fourth or fifth), you get far enough. And you realize there's a *purpose* behind what you're doing. Me, I thought you just got to wander, fight things, find gear, and satisfy that itch to hoard, but there's more! And if you thought it was hard going deeper and deeper.... just wait for the trek back up. But that's all I'll say, as I don't want to spoil anything.Delver is already well-worth the $7.99 it's currently selling for. The visuals are simple and remind me of Minecraft(despite not actually adhering to the same visual format at all), the sprite style is deceptively innocent, colors are vibrant and the lighting is very complimentary to the atmosphere. If you're like me, you'll find yourself creeping, ears sharp. What was that noise? Where did it come from, exactly? What made it??Like I said, it's worth the small price tag, and that's when you know an Early Access game deserves to be Early Access. This isn't a case of "well, it's probably gonna turn into something great given time!" at all. Delver is great, and if you want to pick it up now and get your money's worth early-on, then you'll already have it as it continues to grow bigger and better. Personally, I think I made the right choice hands-down.

content:

Early Access Review
								I love this game!  I've come to realize that I love rogue-likes with a simple design.  The systems don't have to be complex to make the game good, there is depth in how you decide to build your character and how you play.  I just really enjoy playing games like this and Spelunky where it is all about exploration and how you adjust to your environments.  This game just kind of boils down what I love about Spelunky and dungeon crawlers into one delicious gaming soup of goodness.  It makes me happy.

								Delver is a roguelike that is visually similar to all those loveable first person games with billions of sprites (Minecraft, Doom, Wolfenstein etc).As far as gameplay goes, it's a dungeon crawler where you pick up loot and put on the best stuff so that you can KILL MORE MOBS! Aside from that, there is nothing terribly exciting about this game. Combat is boring, there is nothing innovative, and there is nothing really driving me to keep playing. It's not a great roguelike, it's not a great RPG, it's not a great first person shooter/fighter.10 minutes of playtime will show you everything there is to know. Don't bother getting Delver.

number of helpful: 36 of 72 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I beat the game in about 2 hours. It was somewhat interesting, but rather shallow and not very difficult. The player goes down a few floors of a dungeon and then picks up an orb that's guarded by a rather unintimidating boss (I had no idea I had killed him). After you grab the orb, you make your way back to the entrance, which you can basically just rush using a hammer. Bow and arrows are extremely buggy, bouncing all over the place and phasing in and out of reality. While it's an interesting set of ideas, it's extremely slim on content and I feel like I saw the majority of it in two hours, as layouts didn't really seem to change much between my three attempts at getting the orb. I don't think I've ever beat a rougelike in three tries before. I think my opinion on the game would change if they vastly expanded on it, but it looks like it's been in this sort of shape for a while according to the forums.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing graphix style, lacks content Delver is fun little game where you delve into a dungeon fighting monsters and a boss. The thing is, it has a serious lack of content. I would only reccomend this game on sale beceause spending 8 euro's on just two hours of gametime is not worth it in my opinion (a friend of mine completed the game in 0.9 hours without rushing it).The graphix style is amazing. I am a fan of game design in general and this has a serieus amount of potential. The main problem with the game is, as mentioned, the lack of content. As you enter the first dungeon, 'Dungeon 01' will appear on your screen. This gave me the idea there are at least 11 dungeons. Wrong. There is only 1. One single dungeon with only nine floors. If the devs would add at least 10 more dungeons of different styles, I would change my opinion. For now, do not buy this game unless you are curious about the design and need an hour to kill.3/10, potential but propably dead devs.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Though I did enjoy the game, it can be beaten in under 4 hours and the replay value is somewhat disappointing.   I can't recommend this game for over $5 mainly because of its lack of content.  Level-up's are decently-timed, but stat increases often mean nothing (dumping points into Health = always winning).  The game needs to be much longer, and stat increases need to have a much larger impact on the game and its enemies.  You often find yourself randomly finding a nice strong sword within the first few levels and watching the game become extremely easy thereafter.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is retro-style first-person dungeon crawler. It's a very straightforward and fluid experience. The combat is fast, smooth and fun. The loot is plentiful and interesting. Everything serves a purpose and it's easy to figure out what everything does.However, despite the straightforwardness, this is very much a rogue-like. Strong monsters are deadly accurate with attacks and are intelligent. Casters will avoid melee and attempt to kite you. Melee enemies will attempt to flank you. Your skills will be tested and it honestly feels like a match of Quake 3 at times. This is a game you can play for 10 minutes or 10 hours and still lose track of time.

Early Access Review
								 Positive Aspects: Delver is a beautiful game, and I love how immursive it can be at times. I love the loot you can collect in the game.  Negative Aspects: The game is quite repetative, and really there is no point to play over and over. The game is still glitchy, and at random times you can die, or in worse cases loose your progress. The only reason why this game that gets a negative response from me is because how much I hate the general gameplay. Don't get me wrong I love the look at the game and the flow of the game, but I feel like the game is the most tedious game I have ever played!

content:

Early Access Review
								3/5 Delver is a randomly-generated, first-person dungeon-crawler where you try to traverse a cave system to find a magical orb and bring it back outside.Again, it's one of those games that you stop enjoying once you learn how to beat it and then you just breeze through it with minimal effort. The game has low replayability, but I will say it was fun for the first hour or two, but afterwards, I was like "Okay, I beat it. I'm never playing this game agian." It's not a bad game at all, but I can't honestly recommend it. It was a fun little adventure for an hour or two but it got old quickly.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
Early Access Review
								Great fun with lots of potential.  Fiendishly difficult as a Rogue should be:  you will DIE & you will LOVE it.  Charming atmosphere makes the world feel realistic, inviting, & later thrilling.  From the lovely Bard at the begining & throughout, the music is very enjoyable.  The ability to increase speed at level up, & the magic wands scattered about the dungeon are especially enjoyable.  I am quite pleased to be on board for Delver beta. -- If you enjoy slaying monsters in "Minecraft" but hate the platforming, "Delver" is for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall the game is okay, a very basic "rogue-like-lite". It suffers from being a bit weak in scope, but the gameplay is tight. The ending is unbearably annoying, and only has one real playstyle you can do to beat it. I can only suggest the game for $2 or less.If you've ever played a "real" rogue-like, like Nethack (or other ASCIIs) you'll be very disappointed. The game is incredibly limited, the "RPG" element is ultrabasic, with only 2-3 stats actually being useful. There is no character magic, and the game scales pretty linearly. I actually got more out of building up in the first or second dungeons, because while deeper levels bring harder enemies, the rewards are worse.The author put in official mod support, though there is no Steam Workshop. I did not try any of that.Note on other's reviews: Only the first and second dungeons are "procedurally generated" in the normal sense. The others are randomized, but not completely random. It makes the game more interesting, but there are next to no items and as mentioned.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Development isn't entirely abandoned, but a safe bet would be to say no new substantive update would come out this year at all. Go ahead and look for the company's twitter and the dates/frequency/content of posts if you wnat to get a better idea. Dont let the "Early Access" label get your hopes up. Assume this is all you will ever get. At the very least, it needs some optimization updates. This could vary machine to machine but just because your computer is othewise pretty good at what should be harder to process doesnt mean you wont get jarring stutters in this game. Reduction of particles does next-to-nothing to aleviate. There isn't even an update to change the pixel resolution at full screen, or any control customization/mouse sensitivity options whatsoever.Beyond that, the game does have interesting aesthetics but with enemies that could best be described as an annoyance, with melee combat that feels more like a batting range with softballs. Maybe you wont regret buying it on a Steam sale, but if you're budget is 20-30 bucks for the whole sale, look elsewhere.

content:

Early Access Review
								The good: Aesthetically pleasing, nice soundtrack, and smooth gameplay.The bad: Too easy. The only stat that matters is health. If you dump all your stat points into health you'll never have to use a restorative item, ever. You'd have to put genuine effort into dying. Monster AI is boring. The gear is boring. Too many wands spawn. I'd like to see more hidden entrances, unique monsters, unique items, etc. The rollover gold is dumb. I'd rather have no gold at all or have shops inside the dungeon.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm going to preface this review with a disclaimer: This game is very unfinished and while I will recommend it, you should be willing to buy a game that may not get all of the features it promises. I bought the game on sale and I do not regret my purchase. No onto the review.This game, while being described as an action roguelike, is not a roguelike, but a rogue-like-like. It has some roguelike elements but it's missing some of the soul and core mechanics that roguelikes are supposed to have. That doesn't mean it's a bad game, but you should consider this before buying.The basic concept of the game is simple: Delve into the dungeon, make it to the bottom, grab the treasure and escape alive. There are enemies and traps along the way to stop you of course, and the twist of needing to escape with your life adds more difficulty and stress to an otherwise easy game. If you've played a lot of rogue-like-likes before you shouldn't find it too hard to make it to the bottom and beat the boss, but making it back should prove a lot harder. Besides the dungeon, there is also a camp area. The camp area lets you spend your collected gold after you die to start off a run with an item, or items. These items should not be ignored and can give you a very helpful early game advantage. This is a good touch, although I wish more was done with it and the NPCs there. But remeber: The game is still in dev.Overall I'd say Delver is a potentially deep and interesting rogue-like-like with cool ideas, and is worth sticking with for the features planned in the future. The developer has plans to add a lot more depth in items, magic, enemies, character classes and even an overworld with NPCs.

								I've been playing this game for about 12 hours already so I believe I have a fairly good grasp on the game and have experienced 90% of what 'Delver' has to offer. I didn't think this was going to be much of a problem but as the dungeons are very long, I found myself reluctingly sacrificing my progress to take care of my responsibilities in the real world, which is obviously quite frustrating. The only other con to the game is I found the pressure plate traps to be too powerful- but I guess thats personal preference. Overall the game is great and I am looking forward to see what the next updates bring

								Awesome, challenging, but sometimes repetitive. I enjoyed the hours of playing in Delver. The best part for me was the environment. content:

Early Access Review
								Short game, needs more content as well as multiple dungeons/towns to give it a lasting impression. Making your own dungeons gets a little boring after a while since it is 2D. Weapons are limited as is inventory, so some inventory management is needed during gameplay. Shop at camp needs improvement as far as buying and selling items (NPCs are nothing more than area-specific menus). Graphics have been improved a bit, but applying Sphax's pack adds higher resolution textures to the game (though it will remind you more of Minecraft as it does share some of the same textures). Overall, a good game but after a few runs it gets boring fast. Pick it up if it is on sale and you are bored.Graphics: 7/10Sound: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Replay Value: 5/10

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you enjoy dungeon crawling and rougelike games, you will like this a lot. It's features fun combat with procederaly generated maps (that are well designed). Runs are about 30 minutes to an hour + long depending on map layout and any gold you didn't spend that run gets carried over to your next one (Note that runs you did on save file x wont transfer to save file y or z). Beware the sewers however, I have gotten stuck on something there quite a few times and had to abandon my runs. Teleport scrolls are handy for this, but if you don't have one you might be able to get out by throwing out potions and smacking them (Hold w while doing this, also this doesn't work if you are stuck in the geometry or the floor your trying to get to is 2 stories high). The music is also really good. Rate 7/10.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game. First of all, I just wanna say the art style and the music of this game will probably put you in a trance before anything else, secondly (at the time of writing this) acording to one of the main devs, production on the game is going to ramp up soon!It's everything you'd expect from the tags associated with it. It's minimalisticly perfect in that it's not a super crazy fleshed out giant expedition but it has enough meat on its bones to not be played once and forgotten about. Speaking about replayability, it's on par with other huge games like The binding of Isaac and EtG in terms of how many times you can try your luck with RNG in terms of item drops and map layout in attempt to make it to the final boss (which is a good thing if you enjoy a healthy does of luck induced joy/frustration) It's also a perfect gaming for streaming/win-streaking for public amusement IMO... hint* hint*

								So far it's great!  It's a pretty straightforward dungeon crawler, with a unique and fun graphic style.I have three points of critical feedback, fully understanding that this is in Early Access:1. Not sure why I can't leave, I think it would be nice to be able to go top-side and regroup a bit.  Just a suggestion.Other than that, lot's of fun!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Early Access Review
tl;dr at the bottom of the review(I bought the mobile port before buying the game on steam, there will be an explaination that reason below)When I first saw this on mobile I believed that the game wasn't interesting because of the lack of detail with the posted in-game images (as in, 8-bit pixel sprites instead of the 16-bit characters you see now), however during the small and random "Rogue-like" phase of mine, I bought it anyways.And man was I surprised.Bewarned, the graphics are VERY disorenting, but that's just a feature. You'll get over it sooner or later (Looks and Sounds)The game takes on a similar look to Minecraft in a way with it's 16-bit pixel isometric textures, minimal HUD, and virtually astethic delvering music. My experiecne with this is that it's really disorenting on with the FOV and the textures, however over time I got used to them. Yes, it's pixel barf, but you'll get used to it eventually, think of it like a harder version of Minecraft.The music, enemy sounds, and sound effects are all in line with the theme, playstyle and overall idea of the game. each section within the dungeon changes music to the needs of the dungeon's style, and it gets darker and darker as you go. The Enemy sounds are just right, you know that they're there when you get into their line of sight, and that's because they make an annoying sound.From the splashing water, boilling lava and the annoying bat flutter sounds in the distance, the air within the game matches the "delvering" style of the game.It's not easy, but when is a Rogue-like ever easy? (besides those bad ones of course)In my personal opinion, Rogue-like games are the best because you have to master the game in different parts (ex: enemy playstyles, testing unknown potions, etc). Even though I might not master Delver's gameplay (as I have yet to complete ANY rogue-like game) the sense of perma-death and the randomly generated dungeons give the sense of a renewed exploration.You will die a lot in this game, mostly because of something you did wrong. My recommendation? Study the movements of the enemy AI, keep an eye on your health and "git good son"===================/=====================At the end of the day, this game is linear, but it exceeds my expectations of what a rogue-like should be. It's hard, it's complicated and the gameplay is great. I would recommend both the Mobile AND the PC ports of this game because it gives different, but similar gamestyles.And I only found out that there was a PC version because Vinny from Vinesauce actually livestreamed the game on PC. He said it was good and unique, so that kept my hopes up and bought the game on Steam. I honestly didn't know that Delver was first on PC before Mobile, but it's a small world out there.===================/=====================On another note however, from my personal experiences in the game I never really ran into any bugs or glitches of sorts, maybe if I tried I would. Other than that 9/10 great game, I would love to see more content from the devs, but not rushed.A wise gamer once applied the term "Slow and steady wins the race." to games when they are being produced. And I guess he was right in a way.tl;dr (You really should read the full review!)This game is disorienting at first, however you'll get used to it.It sounds and plays good, so you'll like it.It's hard, so "git good"My rating 9/10

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Best First Person Rogue-Like Ever.The developer never stops improving the game, from the complete graphics overhaul, to the changes in character class and leveling, to the changes in dungeon levels and mobs.   There is so much depth to it.Something I said about it on a Reddit post about a year ago, in reference to the Android version which I am also happy to own.   The post was about Delver vs. Barony...  https://www.reddit.com/r/roguelikes/comments/322nst/delver_or_barony_maybe_something_else_entirely/ "I've been playing Delver since before the graphics overhaul and I love it. I own the game on Steam and I also own it on Android. I purchased a portable keyboard for my tablet to go along with my OTG converter, USB hub, and mouse (using a Kinzu for the tablet - the Sensei stays at home) so that I can play it on the go. It's a very fun game. I personally love the new art style and it is a VAST improvement over what the game used to look like. Yes it's very cartoony but it's also not very demanding on your system and it has a good flow. The dev is constantly working on it and like any other good RL, it's a constantly improving and changing game."I still don't own Barony and if I had time in my life, or rather, once I make the time, I plan on checking out Barony as well.  But Delver came first and it is a terrific game.I've played alot of offline hours as well as spent a good deal of time playing the Android version on my Shield Tablet, so don't let my displayed recorded time fool you.If you want an enjoyable, fun, not-too-hard-on-the-eyes (aka "pretty" or even beautiful (which aren't very important words to most hard-core rogue-like fans (but which are to me (and yes this is a digression within a digression within...))), deep FPRL (does that acronym even exist? (and yes I am now hereby banned from using parenthesis)) then buy this game and reward a hardworking independant dev for his tireless efforts.

Early Access Review
								A fun little rouguelike. Recent-ish update saw a nice graphics overhaul from something reminicient of minecraft to a more 16 bit aesthetic. The ability to keep gold earned from previous attempts keeps me coming back, but once you figure out how it's done you can run through the dungeon and make it out alive every time. Still, the game's in beta with more updates sure to come. Got my copy on sale, it's definitely worth the five bucks or so I spent on it. Note: PC version controls a lot better and is a lot more up to date than the android version, but that goes without saying.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								See this discussion post:http://steamcommunity.com/app/249630/discussions/0/282992562606063832/Great game at first.  Smooth controls, nice pixelly first-person interface, roguelike item-distribution, simple level-up system, good map.  Even the melee fighting isn't bad once you get used to it.  You'll find tons of useless items, and occasional upgrades, problems are that you don't have much inventory space, and there's no way to sell items (that I saw). Also, in the shops, you can't see the details (like how much damage) on items you may want to consider buying.  The biggest problem, and dealbreaker, is that once you get a few hours in, something will come along and just instakill you, no matter how prepared you think you are.  It's not worth the time sink.  Perhaps by the time it's out of Early Access this will be addressed.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has great potential to give the player hours of fun traversing winding tunnels through the depths of the endless dungeons to find treasure and glory.  Unfortunately the games graphics are so pixely that even with everything turned all the way up it is very hard for me to discern between the different objects and makes navigating through the different passages quite irritating.  There is a few different graphic packs you can download but the only one worth getting they make you pay for which has turned me off from this game completely.  To the game developer I say make the graphics better and give people a choice between pixely and smooth lines.  For some people who have vision problems like depth perception or color blindness the over pixilazation would cause too much interference to enjoyably play this game.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has great potential. However, combat is unnecessarily difficult (no cursor, no knowledge of enemy hitbox). Most attacks that "should" hit end up missing, which very well may be a game mechanic. My first dungeon run also crashed, and I have experienced jarred graphics and framerate drops randomly throughout a few minutes of play. Full keybinds are tough to figure out without a controls page in the options. You end up dropping gear more often than equiping it.Granted, this is an early-access game, so I will be following it's future updates and improvements.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Its really bad, dont waste your money. It has nothing to do with the game being in early access. The general design choices are horrible. In a good roguelike you can just start playing, clear the levels and have fun.  "Randomized levels - never the same game twice" should actually say: "Randomized levels - almost never get past the first few levels, because we randomly swapped out your starting healing potion for an instant death potion, and we randomly replaced the low level monsters with monsters that have undodgeable ranged attacks that 1 hit kill you."Besides the bad use of randomization the entire combat system is "Hold down left mouse button, let go when neer enermy".Enemy ranged attacks are completely undodgeable because arrows and magic attacks fly faster then bullets. Even worse If you hit, or the enemy hits you is done entirely behind behind the scenes with random rolls based on your stats.There are no choices in classes or races or any way to make your character special. You start with a dagger, a wand with 6 charges, and two completely random potions. You cant buy anything from the shops and you have to go right into the dungeon, and you cant come out until you clear it. You also cant sell anything and there are poison monsters on the first level that will drop your HP down to 1 if one of your two random potions was not an anti-poison potion.In short, the game is bad because whether you win or lose is entirely dependent on luck, and not player skill.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								God horrible. Sure, it has a great combat system, loads of items, and heck, even a great boss fight! However, this game consists of many flaws that ruin the gameplay.1. No Jump Buttons2. Bats that have the glitchiest movement patterns in any game.3. Crazy damage after picking up the Orb, I had full platemail and 60 health, but monsters were still dealing like 6-8 damage! Not the melee, I was fine with that, but the mages were just shooting spell after spell after spell, you couldn't even say "I'm dead" before you're dead.This is supposed to be a rogue game, but only problem. UNFAIR CHALLENGE, you want something fair? Go play Crypt of the Necrodancer, and avoid this abysmal failure for "challenge".P.S: This is Early Access, so it will have bugs, but this is way TOO many.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well done in comparison to most early access titles, Delver manages to keep a simplistic approach to gameplay yet keeps you coming back for more runs. The game allows little room for building your character as you progress, and you are left at the game's mercy when it comes to gear. As you progress deeper into the games dungeon, your play style will rely almost solely on what weapons and armor you find and your luck with the random level generator. Still, the game is a real-time roguelike experience, and much like classic roguelikes, you will often find yourself backpedaling into doorways while trying to kite varied and numerous enemies. It's easy to catch yourself reserving all of your ranged attacks (wands rely on finite charges and bows rely on a rare stock of arrows) for dire circumstances, while searching constantly for a better melee weapon. Armor can be hit or miss, and is often a trade-off between movement speed and protection (both of which are very effective).From death to death, your gold will carry over. The only opportunity to buy items and spells is at the beginning of each run. While the dungeon is currently very short (only seven floors), the environments are nicely varied and the randomly generated rooms keeps it feeling fresh with each attempt. It's worth the price.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Delver feels like a well-polished beta for a game that is nearing completion, which feels really good in a Steam full of early access games left unfinished. I highly recommend playing it if you enjoy fantasy-themed dungeon crawlers or rogue-likes.It runs smoothly with very few glitchs/bugs, and has a great art style and enemy design with excellent semi-randomized levels. The music is spectacular, being in a "simplistic retro" style. The only issues I experienced were with some of the newer levels creating inescapable sub-sections (because of ladders not generating). Player level progression could use an overhaul, since some stats and playstyles don't feel powerful enough, but nothing feels blatantly overpowered, so that can get fixed easily. The game feels complete until halfway through, and without spoilers after that there are several levels which ATM feel like "kill screens" in that they are so small, with the enemy spawn rate being so high, and being in claustrophobic environments.Once you beat the game (or die) your equipped items, inventory, and character levels dissapear, with only your gold being preserved. So a "level+" mode would be a nice touch for beating the game. Also ATM you can buy items from shops, but not sell.It also has a simple but effective level editor, if you're into that.

Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver is definitely worth playing. Think, Legend of Grimrock meets Minecraft... You'll start off as an adventurer in a camp with a random set of gear to get you started. This camp holds shop keepers who can sell you items that will help you on your way, the catch is you probably can't afford anything they sell.Ok so, the deal is this... You start with basically nothing, a pair of "useless pants" and leather armor, an iron dagger, a random magic wand, and a random potion. This means no money, and very little to get you going. However as you play through Delver's brilliantly crafted, procedurally generated levels you'll find gear pretty quickly, and also gold. Once you enter the dungeon there is no leaving until you complete the dungeon, or die. I.E. no going back to to town to restock potions or buy new items. What use is there in having a town in the first place? Well, when you die you lose everything and start a new random dungeon, --but you keep your gold--. So should you die, perhaps you can now afford to buy an amulet with extra armor, or a better weapon to start with. Maybe a scroll of healing, or if you have enough money you can purchase a "skill in a jar" basically a level up. So camp can be pretty helpful if your just having a rough time finding things to get you through. Just keep in mind when you die again these items are lost.So far Delver has only seven floors. I'm hoping that the devs will add more in the future or perhaps make a sort of new game plus mode. In the meantime though, these seven floors are challenging. Hallways, blind corners, randomized traps, enemies from nowhere, and darkness work together to foil your attempts to make it to the next floor. When you finally do make it the floor seven and find the treasure you then have to fight your way back to the top floor with harder enemies spawning all around you. Fighting your way back to the top is almost panic inducing, as you will quickly find yourself scrounging for everly last item, potion and scrap of food, making the final door to the end of the game feel pretty damn satisfying, and fueling an urge to do it all over again.For the love of all that is good play Delver.I for one am looking ever forward to more and more updates to what promises to be a great old school dungeon crawler.

Early Access Review
								Fun Game. Enless hours of fun. The game it self is great and only has a few flaws. The part that i do not like is the level editor. Its the most user unfriendly program ever. I tried to make a level and it took me about an hour then when editing a door it crashes and doenst save the work.... 7/10

Posted: January 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an early impression and not necessarily a "review." Delver is a simplistic first person roguelike with very Minecraft-y graphics.  The first couple of levels are easy but later levels include more agile and clever enemies, especially ranged enemies that like to circle strafe and are difficult to hit.  I'm actually impressed by the conversion of a roguelike to the first person perspective as a lot of roguelike tactics have converted seamlessly: move conservatively, use your items liberally, and lure enemies into hallways to fight them one at a time.When you die, you lose all your equipment but your gold carries over, allowing you to purchase items at the surface shop.  There are a couple of issues I have with the overall design that stem from the simplistic nature.  Specifically, the attributes are seemingly useless with health being the most important as your HP does not increase as you level.  Due to the naure of the random levels, it's very easy for a trap to be placed in a one tile hallway forcing you to walk over it.  This can possibly lead to unbeatable levels as a teleport trap is unavoidable but I have yet to encounter an impossible dungeon.For an early access beta, I'm very impressed.  Delver isn't very feature deep right now but there's plenty of room for it to grow.

Short answer, it's great. Long answer?I actually used to play this way back when it had 8x8 graphics and had just added potions on my laptop and Android phone. It was wicked fun then, and it's just gotten better. Like Eldritch? You'll like this. Like Minecraft? Ditto. If you ever played a roguelike, and wanted it to move just a little bit faster, this is for you. The beta kind of lends itself to a charm, though the frequent updates mean that occasionally your save files will be completely lost. If you're not a fan of that, wait til it's done. But if you want an original dungeoncrawler with a dearth of story and a ton of heart? This is for you.

Posted: January 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s.

Posted: December 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								Delver really brings me back to Daggerfall, it's a fun little randomly-generated dungeon crawler. Enviroments stay fresh, no two playthroughs are alike. Each dungeon level brings new elements and enemies, from easier mages and warriors at the beginning to tough undead enemies at the lower levels. Enemy AI is surprisingly smart for game like this, damage an enemy and it will retreat, prepare to swing and the enemy will move to dodge, etc. It's a nice contrast to a game like Minecraft where enemies are programmed to just walk into you until you die. At the ruins level, the difficulty curve spikes, so some tactical thinking is required. You can't just run and gun, and I found myself taking advantage of things like corners and different enemy positions. Delver is a roguelike, so it features perma-death. You can't make your decisions lightly, and that's a good thing.The game has only been out for a few months and it is still in beta so there is still room for improvement. You're essentially restricted to playing a battlemage; the drop rates for things like weapons, wands and scrolls are completely random so you'll need to use a mix of everything to succeed. I think an item that allows the player to recharge an empty wand would help with that. I wish there was a bit more variation in the enemies, it's currently limited to about four or five types per-dungeon-type and some of them (like bats) can start to become annoying after a while. Potions very useful but their stats are generated randomly with every new playthrough, so you need to determine their stats through trial-and-error. If you don't have the food or health/restore potions to afford you the ability to test new potions out, you ignore them, and they start to build up in your inventory. I love the randomly-generated aspect of this game but if they were color-coded (red for health, blue for magic, etc.) and still used randomly generated stats it would make using potions more convenient.Those are just minor things though, Delver is still a great indie title with a lot of potential and I'd highly reccomend it, especially if you're a fan of the early Elder Scrolls titles.

Posted: December 31, 2013
Early Access Review
Short answer, it's great. Long answer?I actually used to play this way back when it had 8x8 graphics and had just added potions on my laptop and Android phone. It was wicked fun then, and it's just gotten better. Like Eldritch? You'll like this. Like Minecraft? Ditto. If you ever played a roguelike, and wanted it to move just a little bit faster, this is for you. The beta kind of lends itself to a charm, though the frequent updates mean that occasionally your save files will be completely lost. If you're not a fan of that, wait til it's done. But if you want an original dungeoncrawler with a dearth of story and a ton of heart? This is for you.

Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								 For the 2 hours I've already put into it, I've got a really good feeling about it. For one, it perfectly re-captured my nearly 15 year old nostalgia for that cross marketing classic: Chex Quest.... you look confused.You see, it wasn't simply a bald faced endorsement for low sugar breakfast cereals and the General Mills corporation, it was also just a damn good Doom clone. There's something about CQ that I'll never let go of, and it's something no other game has reminded me of since. Except Delver for some reason. The 2-D characters in a 3-D environment is big part of it, but the way the combat works and the way the camera moves just feels so... so cozy.But if there's no fond memories for you there, the looting, leveling, and hack'n'slashing, will do you just fine for $8. There feels like hours of content in here and the 6 run throughs I've done have felt completely different from each other. It certainly feels like a finished product to me.

Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've enjoyed this game, but it's a tenative recommendation I give with the following advice: try rougelike games first, see if you like them. This puppy's more a dog for fans of Ultima Underworld, for those familiar with the game, than someone looking for a first-person, cartoony Diablo. Which *was* the developer's goal and they need to be commended for their efforts: the game, for what it is, is in my opinion a good but (right now at least) somewhat limited game, and one that's still in development besides. See if you like any of the free rougelike games out there- if not Rouge itself. See if you like games with very little plot to speak of (Doom did have a plot; Super Mario Bros. 3 as well). Read up on Delver and games like it just a bit. And thenm when you're ready, take the plunge: $8 is really quite a deal for a charming little pick-me-up game like this (relatively easy deaths means this game is "just one more try" obsession-ready, so bear this in mind too). God speed.

Posted: January 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bean Bag Buccaneers is a two player children's game, the object of which is to pick up your treasure chest on the central island and sail back safely.Each player has a giant sailing ship as their main game piece. Each ship has a removable sail, two trigger-action side panels, and a huge spring-driven cannon. Players take turns moving forward along a prescribed track and shooting bean bags at their opponent's ship. A hit on one of the side panels will force it to pop off and give the player a free shot at the other side; a hit forcing the sail off becalms the ship for a turn.To add to the pirate flavor, each player also has an eye patch. Wearing these will slightly affect depth perception and add a marginal bit of sport to the shooting.This game retailed for the somewhat impressive sum of $16 back in 1962. With its huge plastic ships (close to a foot long), giant vinyl play mat, and the eye patches, it may well stand as one of the more overproduced games of the early 1960s.

Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver is a dungeon crawler that is currently available in Early Access. Because of this, things I say about it may change as development continues.Delver is a very simple first-person dungeon crawler: you start above ground with the task of Delving down several levels to retrieve an orb and return it to the surface. This is the gist of the story, and all you really need.Along the way you'll collect loot, level up and customize your character, and fight hoards of orcs, spiders, bandits, and skeletons.The game is great fun and simple enough to be picked up by anyone. Although initially challenging, I found that the game is exceptionally forgiving if you pump a lot of points into HP. The leveling system provides some flexibility to create what character you want to play, although this really only boils down to what weapons you will use the most.The game is relatively short at this time, and I managed a successful run through very quickly. Even though character deaths mean starting over, I was able to finish the current game in about 4 hours. Levels are supposedly procedurally generated, but I noticed very similar set pieces several times on consecutive play throughs. Nevertheless, I still recommend the game. I'm very excited to see where the game's development takes it, and the inclusion of a level editor promises some interesting modding can be done.For the price of 8 dollars (I picked the game up on sale for 3), I do recommend the game wholeheartedly.

Short answer, it's great. Long answer?I actually used to play this way back when it had 8x8 graphics and had just added potions on my laptop and Android phone. It was wicked fun then, and it's just gotten better. Like Eldritch? You'll like this. Like Minecraft? Ditto. The beta kind of lends itself to a charm, though the frequent updates mean that occasionally your save files will be completely lost. If you're not a fan of that, wait til it's done. Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								A wonderful addition to the ever growing "Rogue-Like" population. Charming graphics, great music, and good atmosphere. I've only clocked in under 3 hours so far but I already see the insane amount of potential here. As of right now you start in the Overworld with a chance to browse a few shops and gear up provided you have any gold (Gold is persistent as of right now). After a bit of shopping it's time to head down to your inevitable death. You'll then be roaming floor after floor for the best loot and enemies to defeat. Combat consists of melee, ranged, and magic: everything an RPG player could ever want or need. Combat is fairly simple. Hit them and don't get hit. If you die well it's back to the beginning for you my friend. Delver also seems to be fully moddable and the dev encourages you to do so. If you fancy yourself a fan of Rogue-Likes and don't mind a challenge...I highly recommend this little gem. **Still in Early-Access**

Posted: December 6, 2013
Early Access Review
								Tremendously fun so far! I love the graphical style and the music. It's a simple game that has great potential and I hope that it will be continued to be expanded by its author. As it is, it's relatively short. I finished it on my third try. The first time I didn't know what I was doing and died quickly. The second time I was more careful and made it to the end, but didn't realize I was near the end, and so I died again. The third time I was prepared, and beat the game. The gold / buying stuff is handled in an interesting way; the gold you collect can only be used to buy things in the NEXT game you play. So while you don't keep levels, items, etc after you die, you do gain an advantage the next time. There are a few annoying things, which will hopefully get fixed in later versions. Some are glitches, like enemies getting stuck in walls. Others are interface things; I found switching between weapons in the middle of combat didn't always work as well as I'd like. However I'd say that Delver is worth buying ... I probably won't play it again until it's next update, but I'm looking forward to doing so.
