Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								First and foremost, I will say that although I personally find this game's simple visual style and interface quite appealing (although it could use some sort of noclip mechanic to help with getting stuck in terrain), it occasionally makes me nauseous while playing for more than a few minutes.      As a fan of brutally difficult roguelike and platformer games, as well as difficult games in general (I love NetHack, Spelunky, The Binding of Isaac, the original arcade version of Ghosts n' Goblins, etc.), I bought this game due to the "roguelike" tag.     Every item is Delver is identified before you even pick it up, save for potions (identified after drinking the first of that color).  And there is only one negative potion effect out of six or so, a weak poison that is easily counteracted by eating any piece of food.     Delver has only 7 dungeon floors to its name, which are procedurally generated, true, save for the last, which is actually a fixed map.  Delver also lacks shopkeepers on floors, instead, there are only two NPCs, and they are on the surface above the dungeon.  So your character ends up carrying a bunch of gold with no way to spend it except by returning to the start or dying.    When dying in Delver, you lose everything except your gold.  This gives you a chance to buy an item when you start a new game to give you an edge, but the high prices ensure that you cannot buy a good item on every run.     The enemies in the first levels of Delver are relative pushovers (as well as possessing primitive AI that can only charge at the player in a straight line, think Minecraft Beta hostile mobs).  Most enemies in the game supposedly have no more than 4 HP, but player attacks seem to deal a lot less damage than they should according to weapon descriptions.  Charging attacks makes them hit every time, which makes fast charging weapons like daggers and shortswords much more effective than larger weapons like hammers or swords.     The enemies get more advanced as you proceed, starting with bandits and slimes and advancing to spiders and floating squid things, orcs and worms, and eventually skeletons and floating skulls.  Zombies and worms can cause the poison effect, which damages health.  Though the enemies are nice so far, there are issues with surround sound in this game.  Bandits commonly yell threats as they see you, but the sound seems to come out of the opposite speaker of their direction, e.g. I hear "You're dead!" out of my rear right speaker, when the bandit is actually approaching from my left.  Given how much I've come to rely on surround sound in this type of game, this can be frustrating.     **** the mages on the first two levels.  I have died to those guys way too many times.  Enemies cannot use bows, only magic and melee.  Melee enemies are easy to deal with, but magic can get annoying.  More annoying is the death screen, which often prevents you from knowing what exactly killed you.  This means you don't necessarily know what you did wrong to get you killed.     The level up system has six stats.  Each time you level up, the game randomly chooses three for you to pick from to increase.  Health, attack, defense, speed, agility (attack speed), and magic (increases wand charges and wand damage).  I find that health is always a priority.  I try to get my health to 16, then start putting points into speed and agility.  Attack, defense, and magic are usually made obsolete due to finding better equipment.  Note that to my knowledge, the other stats also increase by a small amount on level up, but the one you pick goes up by much more than the others.     Though this game is simple, it is not necessarily easy every run.  I can see this game getting much better once all the glitches with getting stuck in terrain are fixed.  I find that this game is actually quite fun if you are into dungeon crawling and exploration, and the surplus of loot is due to the ending.  At the end, you need to escape the dungeon with the treasure while being pursued by endless skeletons and skeleton mages, currently the hardest respawning enemies in the game, in addition to the extremely fast and mobile floating skulls.  The many supplies you find on your way down are basically preparation for this difficult rush section.  Upgrading speed comes in extreme handy for this action packed portion of the game.  The game has limited enemies and environments, but it is in beta and the soundtrack is solid as-is, and the enemies have enough diversity to vary with the current levels.Most of the enemies with AI that only charges straight at you are gone after the first two levels.Features I would like to see added:Noclip or some other system to deal with getting stuck in terrain without having to delete your saveBetter bandit AISpiders should deal poison instead of worms (It's gaming tradition!)Many more floorsMore level varietyMore enemiesEnemies that use bowsMore gold, shopkeepers and NPCs on floorsArmor with secondary effectsSomething that fits in the glove slot, which is currently unusedMore bosses and maybe even minibossesMore types of trapsMore hidden doors and passagesEaster eggsLocal or online co-op could be really awesome if done right (of course, the difficulty level would have to drastically increase as well)I won't put PvP arena on here because it wouldn't add to the game IMO.  Delver is a PvE type game.

Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver's art style and gameplay are reminiscent of older titles like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D, but it's most definitely a roguelike. There are a variety of weapons and items to find and use, with potions' effects changing for each playthrough. Though its replayability is not as great as I expected, Delver stays fresh and fun for many, many hours. Its random dungeon generation does provide for a unique experience for each individual delve (heh) into the deep. Overall, this is a very solid game. Heck, this thing is still in Beta.I can say with absolute certainty that I thoroughly enjoy Delver, and I cannot wait to see what the final product will look like.9.5/10

Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is one of the best First Person pixel games ive seen in a long time. When I first started playing the game I thought of it as tedious and unoriginal. Boy was I wrong, it only seems like alot of other games untill you get further in the dungeons. I had my heart skip a beat at every corner in the sewers. The way that a spider from across the map can echo deep into another part of the cave is spinetingleing. And since once your charecter dies you have to start over you can become legitamently scared for your pixelated life. A few problems I have had though are that the hardest enemy in the game can be bats. They take a lot more hits then they should be able to and have drivin me insane in the deeper levels. This game is glorious and would benefit greatly from Co-Op Multiplayer. But even as a single player game this is a must buy.

Posted: February 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								First person rogue-likes are very fun if done well, and Delver is one example of a first person rogue-like done well. At times it's aesthetics can get annoy. I honestly think there are too many pixelated games these days, and this one does not pull it off too well. But other than that there are many different levels in this game that all are very unique and have their own (how do I put it?) presence to them, they all feel very different. One might make you feel like a spelunky, and the next might give you chills. As fore weapons there are many different sword, the two main categories are one-handed and two-handed. One-handed weapons can be paired with a shield and are quicker to swing. At points it might seem like the reach on your weapons seem a little far fetched, but over all the combat is descent and the sense of adventure will ceep you entranced!

Some of the game's mechanics don't work, such as the gold (you can acess shops in the begining, but you die in the dungeon with the gold. Overall I give this game an 8.5/10.

Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver is a dungeon crawler that is currently available in Early Access. Because of this, things I say about it may change as development continues.Delver is a very simple first-person dungeon crawler: you start above ground with the task of Delving down several levels to retrieve an orb and return it to the surface. This is the gist of the story, and all you really need.Along the way you'll collect loot, level up and customize your character, and fight hoards of orcs, spiders, bandits, and skeletons.The game is great fun and simple enough to be picked up by anyone. Although initially challenging, I found that the game is exceptionally forgiving if you pump a lot of points into HP. The leveling system provides some flexibility to create what character you want to play, although this really only boils down to what weapons you will use the most.The game is relatively short at this time, and I managed a successful run through very quickly. Even though character deaths mean starting over, I was able to finish the current game in about 4 hours. Levels are supposedly procedurally generated, but I noticed very similar set pieces several times on consecutive play throughs. Nevertheless, I still recommend the game. I'm very excited to see where the game's development takes it, and the inclusion of a level editor promises some interesting modding can be done.For the price of 8 dollars (I picked the game up on sale for 3), I do recommend the game wholeheartedly.

Posted: September 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game so far. This isn't as much a review as it is my thoughts on what the developers should change, as this game is still in development and has frequent updates (which is awesome. frequent updates are awesome.)I love the art, although it's a little low res for me. Doom, the game this game's 2D-sprite-in-a-3D-world style is based off of, has higher resolution sprites and textures than this. I understand it's going the retro pixel art route, but it's honestly just kind of lazy to have characters this low resolution. Also, the blood is a little rediculous to me. Everything about this game screams "E for Everyone" then you go ahead and have these really stupid looking blood puddle decals that are left wherever you kill an enemy. I'm not saying this game isn't fit for kids, but it just looks odd and out of place. Either go a mature route and make the characters and art more realistic or take the blood out.The combat is kind of wonky. You hold down Left Click to charge up your attack, and the longer you hold it down the more damage it does. So you can either stab an enemy a bunch of times or give them a couple big, strong slashes. I understand what they're trying to go for, they're trying to make the combat more intuitive, but it doesn't work, mainly because you slow down when you charge your attack. So If you're trying to charge your attack you end up walking painfully slow towards your opponent, and I can understand it's for balancing purposes, but it honestly is just annoying and slows down combat.And probably the most annoying part about the game so far to me is hit detection. Since the characters are 2D sprites instead of 3D models, it can be really hard to tell if you're close enough to them to attack, and often times sword fights just turn into me slashing into the air not close enough to hit them, then moving closer to hit them and getting hit. It's especially annoying with enemies that don't actually attack you, they just touch you and you get hurt, because you're trying to get close enough to hit them but instead of hitting them you get too close and get hurt.I don't really like the music much, but I'm sure a lot of other people like it so I won't tell you to change it or anything, so I just turn the music off. But when you do that, you pretty much hear the torch noise on infinite repeat. It's understandable, because the game takes place in a dungeon lit by torches, but it's so, so incredibly annoying. Either turn the torch noise down, add different ambient noises, or make better music. Any one of those options would be awesome. Besides that, though, the sound effects are awesome.Although it has a couple minor problems, it's still a really fun game, and I recommend it. The magic in this game is really awesome, the feeling you get casting spells in this game is really unique, and the AI isn't bad. The level design is solid, but this game could definitely use some more rooms, I run into the same rooms fairly often. Bottom line is, it's a fun game that has potential to be a great rouge-like.

Posted: August 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fantastic game of procedural dungeon crawling, satisfiying real time combat, and exploration. Delver contains smooth RPG-like combat, where by charging your attack makes it more likely to hit your target (guarenteeing a hit when fully charged); a mysterious setting of an anchient tower holding one of the greatest treasures known; and oogles of replay value.Even though the game is currently in Early Access Beta, it feels well polished, and expertly crafted. Every update adds in more generation to every level in the game, and there are very few if any bugs to be found. The game has a very fair-unfair bipolar, in the early levels, the enemies are relatively easy to dispatch, but if they land a hit, it can take a sizable amount of health away; and towards the end, your going to run out of health a LOT.Delver is a relatively short game; you trek through 10 levels per playthrough of ever increasing difficulty, fight and defeat (as far as I am aware) a single boss, and make an excruciatingly hard, and harrowing journey back up to the surface from whence you came. The final level is the MOST unfair and difficult level in the game, and is probably the one and only constant level throughout your journey, as it appears unchanged through each playthrough. It introduces several enemy types not seen before on any level, and ALL of them hit really, really hard. I have never successfully managed to beat the final boss, and have only made it to him twice.All in all, it is very challenging, and you will die a LOT, but it never feels like you couldn't stop it from happening. Delver is an incredibly fun, semi-addicting, dungeon crawl with danger lurking around every corner, and an unfair boss level.

								I have owned this game on mobile for ome time now, and I just recently bought the game on Steam. Let me say, this game does not disappoint. Posted: April 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short review: If you like dungeon exploring and the challenge of perma-death, in a game that manages to balance that challenge with enough play to keep you coming back, you shoudl check Delver out.Long review: The graphics are "Minecraft-like" for lack of a better way to put it. They're 3d 16 bit, nothing fancy, but they work. It definitely adds to the retro feel.The gameplay is the same first person dungeon exploration that harkens back to Ultima Underworld. It's balanced and challenging. There is a learning curve but you will find yourself delving deeper on each try and more importantly, wanting to try again after each death.This is one of the few perma-death games that get it right. It isn't frustrating but also is not easy.  Don't get me wrong, one moment of stupid can cause a restart but the build to your character is balanced with the difficulty in such a way as to make you avoid mistakes and almost always understand exactly why you died when/where you did. This balance is what makes me want to keep coming back and keeps me trying to delve deeper into the dungeon and hone my skills. I've tied a lot of these rogue-like games with perma-death recently and this one definitely stands out a a diamond in the rough.

Posted: October 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is one of those games, like many other rogue-likes, that always draw me back for short bursts of play. It has a lovely art style, which has a very cartoonish aspect to it, the gameplay is challenging enough for it to be fun, and the gear you find is well balanced so you aren't likely to find an over set of gear in the first level (although that can still happen, occassionally).The pros:- Good art style- Simple controls; can be played without a mouse- Hints of a bigger story and plot to the game- Balanced loot- Good for short bursts of gameplayThe cons:- Bugs in the terrain, can glitch out of the map- Making it to the end of the dungeon ramps the difficulty up tremendously- Skills aren't labeled to what they effect; there is a skill for agility and speed, one effects movement, the other attack speed of weaponsThat about does it, in all, Delver is good, but still needs improvement. Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fun, first person rogue-like dungeon crawler and it's pretty fun. Even though I beat it after 3 times, I still want to play again. I beat it fast, but it's still in early access, so many things can be changed. Now to the overall score;GAMEPLAY is really fun and satisfying. While I played I developed a tactic for each enemy, taking them out really fast. for example when a worm is about to jump-attack, I wait just the right moment to strike and take it down. 9/10VISUALS is actually pretty good despite the fact it is pixel graphics. However, graphics shouldn't decide if game is good or not, but it's still nice to look at. The inventory system is really easy use and understandable 8.5/10LEVELING. The leveling system cool. I like games when you level up your character and tweak your stats. Even though the most important stat in my opinion is HP, that's how I won the game. But you can only level up one stat by choosing 3 random stats everytime, so it's not always you can level up HP. 8.5/10DIFFICULTY. This game isn't really that hard, but it's not that easy either. For example, the magic wands is really good/ kinda op. I didn't need to level up magic at all, and they were still pretty good. It's in early access, so it can be changed. 8/10So all in all I give this game a 8.6/10. It's not perfect, but it can be improved! If you like rogue-likes buy it. If you like dungeon crawlers, buy it. It's even on sale when I write this review. BUY IT NOW! :D

Posted: April 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's not entirely unlike Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, in the style and story (1. Reach bottom of dungeon; 2. Grab shiny orb of arbitrary unexplained power; 3. GTFO while being pursued by respawning enemies). However, Delver is a much shorter and more straightforward game, and is a real-time roguelike rather than a turn-based one. But despite, or perhaps because of, its short length (7 floors, easily completable in an hour or two) it is incredibly fun. It has the right amount of RNG; enough to keep things fresh with new layouts and items, but not so much that you can ever really get wrecked by random factors beyond your control. Every run feels winnable; every death feels like it could have been avoided if you had just played better. Plus it has a level editor now, and is still under active development, so there's lots of potential for more things in the future.

Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I seem to be playing a lot of Roguelikes recently, and this game is pretty darn good for Early Access.Your mission is to explore the dungeon and find the orb at the bottommost floor, fighting through groups of people, bugs (ick), bats and skeletons. Get the orb and do your best to escape alive, because everything comes back at you threefold once you pick up the darn thing. The first-person perspective, coupled with a few small corridors and narrow walkways, really give you a mild sense of fear and excitement--you never know what's going to jump out from behind the wall (hopefully not a magic-user).The game is pretty short. For some players, you could run through the whole thing and escape alive in only about 3 attempts. But don't let that deter you, as it is a lot of fun regardless. That being said, I would strongly suggest picking this game up when it's on sale, as there is a lot to be desired. Still, it IS Early Access...Also, sometimes I feel like I'm being cheated. I went down there with around 80 arrows, never found a bow, found the orb instead, tried to escape, made it back up to the first floor and FINALLY found a single bow to use the arrows with. Great...

Posted: October 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is one of those games, like many other rogue-likes, that always draw me back for short bursts of play. It has a lovely art style, which has a very cartoonish aspect to it, the gameplay is challenging enough for it to be fun, and the gear you find is well balanced so you aren't likely to find an over set of gear in the first level (although that can still happen, occassionally).The pros:- Good art style- Simple controls; can be played without a mouse- Hints of a bigger story and plot to the game- Balanced loot- Good for short bursts of gameplayThe cons:- Bugs in the terrain, can glitch out of the map- Making it to the end of the dungeon ramps the difficulty up tremendously- Skills aren't labeled to what they effect; there is a skill for agility and speed, one effects movement, the other attack speed of weaponsThat about does it, in all, Delver is good, but still needs improvement. I reccomend this game.

Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a fun, first person rogue-like dungeon crawler and it's pretty fun. Even though I beat it after 3 times, I still want to play again. I beat it fast, but it's still in early access, so many things can be changed. Now to the overall score;GAMEPLAY is really fun and satisfying. While I played I developed a tactic for each enemy, taking them out really fast. for example when a worm is about to jump-attack, I wait just the right moment to strike and take it down. 9/10VISUALS is actually pretty good despite the fact it is pixel graphics. However, graphics shouldn't decide if game is good or not, but it's still nice to look at. The inventory system is really easy use and understandable 8.5/10LEVELING. The leveling system cool. I like games when you level up your character and tweak your stats. Even though the most important stat in my opinion is HP, that's how I won the game. But you can only level up one stat by choosing 3 random stats everytime, so it's not always you can level up HP. 8.5/10DIFFICULTY. This game isn't really that hard, but it's not that easy either. For example, the magic wands is really good/ kinda op. I didn't need to level up magic at all, and they were still pretty good. It's in early access, so it can be changed. 8/10So all in all I give this game a 8.6/10. It's not perfect, but it can be improved! If you like rogue-likes buy it. If you like dungeon crawlers, buy it. It's even on sale when I write this review. BUY IT NOW! :D

Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a good game to play if you want to kill an hour or two.Afterwards, it feels like there's no more reason to continue though. The weapons all behave very much the same. You have your slow close combat weapons, your long range, and your long range with flashy colors.I died more than 5 times from random things. Would be walking along, no enemies around and then die suddenly. Then be forced to completely restart which was very frustrating.I feel like this game could be really really fun though. Maybe hide special weapons around the map that you don't find via killing enemies, but instead in secret optional dungeon rooms that have increased traps and perils? Or maybe even have the ability to find totems or statues that can randomize your items, restart the floor, give you full health, bring you down to 1 health, or give you a very special armor. Somesuch like that. It may be a lot of work, too. But it could also be a very cool idea to make a hub town world with vendors and such as there are before you go into the dungeon. And in the hub area, you could get told of other dungeons to go explore as the same character.Still though, if you're looking to kill an hour or two, I say go for it and get this game. Updates are always bringing fixes and features.In it's current form, 6/10. Not perfect, but not too shabby.

Posted: March 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The first time I reviewed the game I didn't recommend it.  For a roguelike, it's weird I could beat it for what seemed to be my first time in an hour and a half.  The gold you found within the confines of the dungeon was useless to boot.  What about now?  Well the game's on it's 7th update and some interesting changes came around!The level design is much more inspired and varied : for example the cave levels have all sorts of crooked angles and secret paths hidden under foliage.  Very interesting.  There is now vendors within the dungeon to whom you can finally trade your precious gold with.  Other than that I haven't noticed that many changes and it's still a pretty straightforward dungeon crawler. The items you find still have  pretty straightforward uses .The game still looks pretty sweet.  It plays fast too. I haven't played all the way to the end yet  (nearly there if it's as long as the original version I played) but I guess now it feels more like a complete game.  It's still  very simple and short, but for 8 bucks I think any dungeon explorers out there couldn't go wrong giving it a try : ) I appreciate the effort that went into this and it seems it keeps being updated over time.

Posted: August 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is unique in genre. It's an FPS roguelike. Others exist, like Paranautical Activity, but I would call that more of an FPS of Binding of Issac, while Delver is more of an FPS version of Nethack. I love Nethack, and have consequently played far too much of it. This solid FPS roguelike will actually fill that same itch in a fresh new way.The graphics may be offputting, being that they belong more in the Doom era of gaming than they do today, but it is definitely excuted well. And I also do believe that it fits the style of roguelike very well, while allowing the devs to focus on other core gameplay features. And that's where this game really shines. It's built solidly. It may not do a whole ton of things. But the things that it does, it does fantastically.I believe that if this game were to become as popular as the Dungeons of Dredmor, it could bring in a whole new legion of roguelike fans, as DoD did before it. If procedural generation and first person cameras are what you like, give this a try.

Posted: August 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								First person, retro-roguelike, 90's inspired dungeon crawl full of greatass magic staffs, potions, swords, bows, and general food. What more could you possibly ask for? You have your expected gold currency with a shop at the start for extra loot after you got your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you last game - maybe it's just me; you buy it and tell me!Either way, it's randomly generated, entertaining, and simple enough for even the most basic and recreational gamers you can identify. I mean, giant white text that says "YUM" pops up when you eat something. How ♥♥♥♥ing great is that?Not to mention that everytime you play, the map is regenerated, so you can just play over and over and lose your♥♥♥♥♥♥in this gut wrenchingly, childbirthingly, universally cathartic experience that has manifested itself within these breathtaking 32-bit pixels that move jovially at thirty frames per second to my tiny, childish hearts content.Seriously, it's so good, I made up words for this review. I never do that. But you wouldn't know that.Just get the game!

Posted: November 3, 2013
Early Access Review
								Way back when I was younger, my fortunes brought me to a tome, and with it came a circular memory stone containing knowledge of an ancient, stygian abyss. So, I set out and invested many hours exploring that place, combatting all manner of terrors in pursuit of a goal that quickly slipped from my mind and escaped beyond the shadows my meager light could not uncover. It's been many years since that time, and I grow weary to make another attempt on that place. But, now I hear rumor of another ruin, filled with treasures and fiendish traps, as well as maddened explorers who have become trapped in that place. Knowing what fate must surely await me should I not be careful, I stepped beyond that unassuming wooden door, dagger in hand, and pressed on into the darkness. But yeah, anyway, I got ultima underworld by chance with a PC Gamer magazine, and it was great. Delver immediately reminds me of it in style, but with a better interface and faster, shorter gameplay. While I might wish for a little more depth in terms of things to find or do with my character, I can't argue that there isn't already plenty to get the job done. The graphics are crispy and pixellated, with just the right resolution textures to express details where needed and not lose out on that retro charm.

Posted: October 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								--THIS IS A REVIEW OF THE GAME AS OF THE 19TH OF OCTOBER, 2014. THE GAME IS SUBJECT TO CHANGE IN THE FUTURE.--Now, I shall get all of the potential negatives out of the way first. Yes, the game is light on content. With only a few enemy types and one dungeon, skilled players may find themselves quickly consuming all the game has to offer. That, and some occasional bugs that very rarely appear but can be annoying sometimes.With that all said, this game is brilliant value for money. £5.59 for a game as addictive as this is a steal, and in my opinion the dev could get away with charging a little more. The pixel art aesthetic is pulled off expertly, as so many other indie dungeon crawlers are from a top down perspective or 2D, it's refreshing to play a FPDC (first person dungeon crawler). The potion system in the game gives a tense atmosphere when you are at low health, having you gamble with fate as you could consume a health potion, or get a poison debuff alongside many other potion effects. Combat is very simple, but this works in the games favour as it makes all combat encounters very quick, which is essential as it makes runs shorter going hand in hand with the permadeath mechanic.All in all, for the stage it's at now and the price tag it has, this is a great game, and with more content on the way, I highly recommend you buy it now.

Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver, mechanically, is a great, great game. I've had a ton of fun with it so far, and I'd recommend it to just about anyone. Right now it's pretty small, but I have high hopes for it when the full game is released.The combat is very reminiscent of Minecraft, especially the swords and bows, though somewhat more complex. Elemental magic wands are an interesting option, though they're all basically the same. Enemies don't seem to have resistances or weaknesses, and there are no additional effects like the fire wand making enemies catch fire. Still, this is obviously an area the developers plan to expand on in the future, so I'm excited to see what they might add to the combat system.The visuals are really great. There's a satisfying feeling in smashing an enemy backwards and watching him burst into a shower of red pixels, and the various enemies and environments all look fantastic. I was pleasantly surprised by the variety in the different dungeons you trek through. Cave levels are uneven and winding; a sewer I found myself in seemed extremely linear at first, but turned out to have tons of little alcoves and branching paths. Enemies all attack in similar ways (charging forward with melee weapons or shooting magic), but at this point in development it's nice to have some various enemy looks. Honestly, this is a great game by itself. It just needs more... stuff. More content. The levels are pretty linear overall, and the end goal is fairly simple. Some other objectives could be fun... you could happen upon a corpse, with a clue that a great treasure lies hidden nearby. Find it, and you might be rewarded with some powerful armor, or a legendary magic wand. Special named weapons and armor would be so fun to collect, it would keep you coming back into the dungeons for more. I'd also love to see bigger levels, with multiple parts.As of right now, this is a great base for a game. Once they add more content, supporting the already great gameplay with some additional items and places, this could become a favorite.

Early Access Review
								The first time I reviewed the game I didn't recommend it.  For a roguelike, it's weird I could beat it for what seemed to be my first time in an hour and a half. Posted: September 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game so far. This isn't as much a review as it is my thoughts on what the developers should change, as this game is still in development and has frequent updates (which is awesome. frequent updates are awesome.)I love the art, although it's a little low res for me. Doom, the game this game's 2D-sprite-in-a-3D-world style is based off of, has higher resolution sprites and textures than this. I understand it's going the retro pixel art route, but it's honestly just kind of lazy to have characters this low resolution. Also, the blood is a little rediculous to me. Everything about this game screams "E for Everyone" then you go ahead and have these really stupid looking blood puddle decals that are left wherever you kill an enemy. I'm not saying this game isn't fit for kids, but it just looks odd and out of place. Either go a mature route and make the characters and art more realistic or take the blood out.The combat is kind of wonky. You hold down Left Click to charge up your attack, and the longer you hold it down the more damage it does. So you can either stab an enemy a bunch of times or give them a couple big, strong slashes. I understand what they're trying to go for, they're trying to make the combat more intuitive, but it doesn't work, mainly because you slow down when you charge your attack. So If you're trying to charge your attack you end up walking painfully slow towards your opponent, and I can understand it's for balancing purposes, but it honestly is just annoying and slows down combat.And probably the most annoying part about the game so far to me is hit detection. Since the characters are 2D sprites instead of 3D models, it can be really hard to tell if you're close enough to them to attack, and often times sword fights just turn into me slashing into the air not close enough to hit them, then moving closer to hit them and getting hit. It's especially annoying with enemies that don't actually attack you, they just touch you and you get hurt, because you're trying to get close enough to hit them but instead of hitting them you get too close and get hurt.I don't really like the music much, but I'm sure a lot of other people like it so I won't tell you to change it or anything, so I just turn the music off. But when you do that, you pretty much hear the torch noise on infinite repeat. It's understandable, because the game takes place in a dungeon lit by torches, but it's so, so incredibly annoying. Either turn the torch noise down, add different ambient noises, or make better music. Any one of those options would be awesome. Besides that, though, the sound effects are awesome.Although it has a couple minor problems, it's still a really fun game, and I recommend it. The magic in this game is really awesome, the feeling you get casting spells in this game is really unique, and the AI isn't bad. The level design is solid, but this game could definitely use some more rooms, I run into the same rooms fairly often. Bottom line is, it's a fun game that has potential to be a great rouge-like.

Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Summary: A simple, solid game that's reasonably challenging and easy to get into. Heartily recommended.Priority Interrupt describe Delver as having "crunchy pixels", but I'd say that adjective can be applied to the game as a whole. This is a good solid game with a lot about it to like, that you'll be happy to sink your teeth into.This is one of those games with the benefit of simplicity - with familiar controls and clear, uncomplicated mechanics, it's very easy to get into with a learning curve you can get to grips with good and quickly. But it's also one of those games that's easy to learn, hard to master - as you'd expect from a permadeath roguelike, it presents a decent challenge that favours a tenacious and moderately tactical playstyle, but never feels overly unfair. Keep your equipment up to scratch and your wits about you, and you should do fine.

								Despite appearances, much of Delver's charm actually manages to stem from the voxel-based imagery. The combat isn't anything to write home about, but certainly keeps things entertaining as  you journey through randomly generated dungeon mazes. Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								(First of all, in the time that this was written, the game had just received an update after nearly a year, this is because one of the developers had a baby and they had to pause in the development. So if you read any more negative reviews that were made before or around the time this review was made, if they mention anything about the developers not updating, this is why.)Delver is a simple roguelike dungeon crawler that is, I believe, heavily influenced by games like DOOM and Zelda.The objective of the game is to enter a procedurally generated dungeon (Different every time) that consists of several floors with different themes, get the treasure, and return to the surface safely.I don't want to spoil to much, because Delver, I think, is supposed to give you a feeling of wonder, suspense, and the unknown. And, despite being very simple, I feel it somehow does this very well, even after playing the game multiple times. Which I think is why I love it so much. The game is somewhat difficult, maybe even unfair at times, but hey, why would the enemy make it fair in the first place?And also, that is part of the mystery, sometimes, dungeons are full of loot and as you make your way down, you will eventually become nearly invincible, other times, you really have to just make do what you have, and sometimes the traps and the general layout of the dungeon is a real pain in the butt. so, basically, the games difficulty is different EVERY TIME. Which, personally, I think is brilliant. But of course, I highly doubt anyone will be having any competitions with this for $10,000 anytime soon. Which is OK.I cannot express the feeling of winning this, especially for the first time. It makes my day even more than cookies do.Which is saying a lot. I challenge you to beat Delver, if you dare. But remember, it was hidden away for a reason.Edit: Some screenshots I took:

Posted: October 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Delver is one of the few dungeon crawlers that I love. This game has tons of potential to become an amazing dungeon crawler game and with the developer coming back after his first kid i'm hoping we can see more from the developer. In broad terms the game revolves around you delving into a dungeon to retrieve the yithidian orb. Along the way you will pass through different levels/stages all being unique to each other such as sewers/temple etc. All of these levels have different mobs and level design so you wont feel that your facing the same thing over and over(although some of the enemies AI are similar). Also the loot from going into the dungeon is unique enough in its state, with different armor/weapons/ring each with different attributes. The game is like medium difficulty but can be difficult and put a fire under your♥♥♥♥♥at some points. Whenever you die you lose all your items and character progress, but along your playthrough you can collect gold, which can be used to buy items to help your future playthroughs. Combat is basic, with essentialy a charged attack for melee and wands, and shooting your bow and arrow. Although the combat is basic it's satisfying enough to enjoy and play the game over and over again, considering its RNG of level layout and armor. Whenever you level up you are able to choose from a pool of attributes, attack, speed, health etc. The attributes are really basic and some attributes are really underpowered, like defense or magic. The hit box for the enemies are kinda weird, but not annoying to where it becomes a major problem. Also I feel that for a dungeon crawler with getting loot and wanting the player to play again and again, I think it shouldnt make you lose all your items once you beat the game. Instead of losing your items it should let you keep your items, but ramp up the difficulty of mobs and mabye more levels. This would give the game more replay value and make the player feel more "rewarding" instead of just saying congrats you beat the game! and restart your character.The mechanics for the game are basic but fun, it gives you the feel of an actual dungeon crawler, searching for loot and randomized levels. However, I feel the game lacks because it is very basic in some areas(i know its in early access). Only having a charged attack and simple character sheets leaves a lot of room for improvments and gear that can be more unique. The progress of the game has been very slow recently(and I know the developer just had a baby) but hopefully we can see some progress as I've seen the developer working on it on his twitch stream. Delver is one of those games that you come back to every once and awhile and feels new when you do come back to it, and I hope to see this game released in the future because I see potential for Delver becoming an amazing game.

Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I believe I have DELVED in far enough into the game to write my review in its current state. (heh). Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with RPG elements. The art style is personalized and enjoyable to just sit there and look at for a while. But lets get to the nitty gritty. Delver still is very much still in early access. A successful run will take a little more than an hour and its replay ability is good but not that great once you beat the game. The combat is enjoyable but mabeye a bit simplistic and becomes much easier once you learn the movement system. My one big complaint is the ending when you fight the Lich. He only took 4 shots from my 11-18 damadge bow and just nuked you when you were near him tons of damadge. He felt more like a place holder than a real boss. Also when you have to climb back up to the surface it felt like filler and you could just run around the enemys till you got to the top for the most part. In the end Delver is a bit of an investment and at its current state a few hour's of fun.( Have not checked out any mods but apparently the community is great and that would add some time to your hour's)  It's your choice if you want to Invest in this but if your not sure I would wait and follow its development untill it came to a state that you liked, but if the idea really hits home with you pick it up and join the Delver community.

Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fantastic old school dungeon crawler. Given its price, this is a really smart, visually charming, pick-up-'n'-play crawler that manages to have entertaining combat, somewhat varied enemies and plenty of loot to work through. The dungeon levels are randomised, and each play has 7 levels, the last of which contains the Orb you're after. Grinding through each level to the end is great, and battling back up with the orb is even more challenging. There's a very small upgrade element, but by vast majority this is just one of those wee games you have that you jump into occasionally for a quick run around. No strings, no commitment, just a quick half hour of fun whenever you need it. Highly recommended.

Posted: March 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								TLDR: An absolutely fantastic dungeon crawl that is casual and smooth, and feels more like a finished small team indie game than something in early access.Gameplay takes less than a minute or two to get into and is helped by the butter smooth controls and simple control scheme. Attacking, either with magic, a melee weapon or a bow (when you find one) is simple but satisfying with the casual nature of the game.Loot is plentiful and  takes after the genre of roguelikes because items must be used to figure out their effects. The simple hotbar system popular these days lets you see what your useful items are but provides challenge at later levels because potions and scrolls don't stack, leaving you with the choice to equip the scroll of resist magic you might need or the extra healing potion so you don't die.Easy to get into, and hard to pull yourself away from, Delver is a diamond in the rough and offers fun in spades for casual dungeon crusaders.

								Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could. Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.-Comiccomwww.thecomic-community.com

Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is exactly what it looks like, except for the end area. You descend 6 levels, have to pick up an orb, and re-climb them all to get out. When you pick up that orb, you have to deal with infinitely re-spawning enemies throughout the 6 levels, and all the care and patience you took in dealing with them before flies out the window. You leveled only health and made sure I had the best weapons, armor, and healing items you could have before taking the orb. It does not matter. You are swarmed with flying skulls that you cannot outrun and must fight. As you do so, Skeleton mages bombard you with magic from beyond the game's very tiny draw distance, and you die. In a game about resource managemeant and dungeon delving, rushing things leads to death, and the game forces you to do so.I do not recommend this game, and doubt it will be fixed.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								In my own opinion (please don't hate me internets) this is one of the best roguelike games out there.  The art style is charming, the music is catchy, and the environments keep the dungeon from getting to stale and repetitive.  I've been playing this game since it was in the alpha stages before it was even on Steam, and every time an update is released, it introduces new and exciting features to the game.  One of the strongest features though is the balance between difficulty, length, and permadeath.  The game isn't tremendously long, but it is quite challenging.  This is fantastic because when you win it feels like an accomplishment, but if you die it isn't a crippling blow as you were probably only 3-6 floors down.  Another 20 or 30 minutes and you could potentially get there again.  This game is a hidden gem of the indie developer scene and I sincerely hope it receives the recognition it deserves.

Early Access Review
								Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could. Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.-Comiccomwww.thecomic-community.com

Posted: December 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is easily one of the most immediately enjoyable games I've played.  It takes the familiar rogue-like formula and gives it an unusual first-person treatment and a surprising amount of depth from its seemingly simple system.  If you are a fan of hack-and-slash, stat-based RPGs, rouge-likes, or just a quick, accessible action game, Delver delivers.  My only gripes are with the difficult inventory menu.  It would be nice if the game paused while it was active and it's hard to get in and out of quickly.  I haven't found a way of identifying potions besides trial and error, and with limited health restoration, this can be deadly.  Random death is not good.Also, there are places where jumping feels needed, but there seems to be no jump feature.  It never breaks the game, but I notice the lack of it.

Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Delver is a good game to play if you want to kill an hour or two.Afterwards, it feels like there's no more reason to continue though. The weapons all behave very much the same. You have your slow close combat weapons, your long range, and your long range with flashy colors.I died more than 5 times from random things. Would be walking along, no enemies around and then die suddenly. Then be forced to completely restart which was very frustrating.I feel like this game could be really really fun though. Maybe hide special weapons around the map that you don't find via killing enemies, but instead in secret optional dungeon rooms that have increased traps and perils? Or maybe even have the ability to find totems or statues that can randomize your items, restart the floor, give you full health, bring you down to 1 health, or give you a very special armor. Somesuch like that. It may be a lot of work, too. But it could also be a very cool idea to make a hub town world with vendors and such as there are before you go into the dungeon. And in the hub area, you could get told of other dungeons to go explore as the same character.Still though, if you're looking to kill an hour or two, I say go for it and get this game. Updates are always bringing fixes and features.In it's current form, 6/10. Not perfect, but not too shabby.

Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I haven't been scared by a game so effectively for a while.Let's see, I'm gonna talk about the levels, the monsters, the gameplay, and character growth.LEVELS:The levels are premade rooms randomly sewn together as is common practice. The design of the rooms is very good, though the game needs more variety, still. The only outside area is the starting point, unfortunately. Going underground, there are the dungeons. Then there are cavey caves. Then there are sewers. Then there is lava...you'll have to play for more details. There are bottomless pits, pulleys and levers, keys and locked doors, doors that you have to bash down, secret doors, and trap-plate traps (teleporter traps are kinda annoying).MONSTERS:The monsters seem to fall into a few categories, which are perfect for the gameplay setup. There are fast dodging monsters (bats, flying skulls), typical meaty melee fighters (thugs/bandits/giant spiders), jumping melee fighters (they jump at you when you get close, hard to time attacks), and magical ranged fighters. Perhaps there should be some physical ranged monsters or magical melee ones? There probably will be later. The monster difficulty balances well with player development and the combat shines.GAMEPLAY:Getting onto gameplay, most everyone else has already mentioned it, the combat is very decent and straightforward; melee weapons are more dangerous to use because you might be hit (and starting out HP is very scarce). Thankfully they don't break over time like other games. Ranged weapons are bows and arrows and wands that have limited ammo. Though missed arrows can be picked up, wands never recharge. As it is a roguelike, don't expect ammunition to be too plentiful, especially for the late game. Potions are random but scrolls are not. Potion effects take about 2-3 uses to learn what they are (which I think is dumb because the player can remember them...and after playing a few times having to re-remember just gets annoying [Note to the maker: can we have it be just one potion use == in-game player learns it?]).PLAYER DEVELOPMENT:For character development, as far as I can tell, in the late game, increasing your attack or magic seems worthless. If you are good at predicting monster movements, even if your attack is low, you can take as many hits as you want without getting hit. Near the end of the game, no matter how good you are, once you start getting swarmed by mage-skeletons and flying skulls, you're gonna get hit a lot, so my advice is put most of your points into speed, health, and defense. If you ever get swarmed well...RUN!MY MAIN THOUGHTS:1) Magic is a stat that seems mostly useless, I can't imagine relying on wands near the end game when there are a lot of monsters but probably not nearly enough dropped wands, nor inventory space to hold them. Same with arrows. This is a minor balance concern that can be directly adjusted, but what I'd really rather see is a more traditional MP and learned spell system, also wands that recharge for those who are not magically-inclined.2) I 100% wish the game wasn't just a roguelike and was more developed as an RPG. The music, graphics, and engine are so awesome, I don't want my game to end just because...I won. I want more. I would pay a full $60 to play just a Diablo clone with this engine, graphics, musical, and dungeon layout feel.3) So, I was looking at the development log and there's an awesome overhaul coming to the editor. Until it comes, the current map editor is essentially unusable and the assets needed to mod the game aren't readily available so it's not really even close to being as moddable as I'd hoped. My main reason for buying this game is cause I heard it was uber-moddable. I hope as it develops the assets are more open. Modding is what opens small games like this to the masses and makes them become legendary.4) I am in love with this game. It is very charming.Pros:- Fast, easy to learn, first-person roguelike- Good music and graphics schemes- Fluid gameplay, sensible difficultyCons:- Needs more content- Without modding, little replay value

								I believe I have DELVED in far enough into the game to write my review in its current state. (heh). Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler with RPG elements. The art style is personalized and enjoyable to just sit there and look at for a while. But lets get to the nitty gritty. Delver still is very much still in early access. A successful run will take a little more than an hour and its replay ability is good but not that great once you beat the game. The combat is enjoyable but mabeye a bit simplistic and becomes much easier once you learn the movement system. My one big complaint is the ending when you fight the Lich. He only took 4 shots from my 11-18 damadge bow and just nuked you when you were near him tons of damadge. He felt more like a place holder than a real boss. Also when you have to climb back up to the surface it felt like filler and you could just run around the enemys till you got to the top for the most part. In the end Delver is a bit of an investment and at its current state a few hour's of fun.( Have not checked out any mods but apparently the community is great and that would add some time to your hour's)  It's your choice if you want to Invest in this but if your not sure I would wait and follow its development untill it came to a state that you liked, but if the idea really hits home with you pick it up and join the Delver community.

Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Simple Review  here:Delver is a rogue-like dungeon crawler where the player's only goal is to get to the bottom of the dungeon (7th floor), grab the Yithidian Orb, and return to the surface with it. What's the catch? Well I'm glad you asked. As previously stated, there are 7 floors in total. The first two are the Dungeons, the next two are the Caves, the next two are the Sewers, and the final stage is the dreaded Ruins. This game can have a somewhat steep learning curve, but it is very fun because each playthrough is an entirely new experience. Here's why. The dungeons are all procedurally generated (which means you get entirely new maps every time you play), the items one may acquire vary in quality and location, and all potions change in their function. The red potion may be healing or magic resistance the first time through, but it may be poison or physical damage resistance the next time through. These qualities are what make this game a Rogue-like. This is also a First Person game and there are NO PUZZLES for those of you who hate puzzles haha. Pros:+ The graphics are very well done, stylized in a 16-bit, pixelated vibe. + The music is very pleasing and enjoyable. It is fitting for floor's theme and atmospheric as well. + The controls are simple and easy to learn.+ The game makes leaps and bounds with every update provided.+ It has a surprisingly addictive learning curve.+ Difficulty is good enough to where you may finally beat the game one time, but when you go back to try again you can't make it. +Enemy AI is good. The various enemies have various attack patterns and styles, even methods of movement. + A somewhat complex weapon system in which there are several types of weapons such as the bow, wand, hammer (2-hands), and long sword just to name a few. Each weapon has its own knockback, damage, and range. + The leveling system is unique in this game in that you get to choose from 3 randomly chosen stats out of 6 total stats: Agility, Attack, Defense, Health, Magic, and Speed. + Can create various character builds according to the stats you want, the stats your given each level up, and the amount of armor you choose to wear. + Armor affects speed and defense: The more defense, the less speed in general. + Tons of replay value and plenty of good texture packs and mods to extend the game and make it more challenging. . . even adding new types of floors and enemies!+ Items do not carry over after death, but gold does.+ I greatly enjoy how you start at a base camp every time that contains two vendors who can sell you things after you collect enough gold in the dungeon. If you're lucky, you may come a cross a vendor in one of the first two floors as well. Cons:- There are still a few bugs to work out such as items randomly getting stuck in walls and making this atrocious sound that cuts out the music for the rest of your journey. - Another bug would be the bow sometimes passing right through enemies or just bouncing off. Some of the enemies may just have ridiculous hit boxes (looking at you floating eye). - Other than those two bugs, I never really came across anything that was bad or wrong. - Pick your poison here: Runs can take you anywhere from 30 minutes (if you're really good and have lots of experience) to 1 hour and 30 minutes or longer (if you're a noob). - For some players, the luck factor that comes in to play when discovering gear, the distance from the entrance of a floor to the exit of a floor, and the number of enemies that spawn, may not be entirely enjoyable as it will feel as if the odds are against you a bit too strongly at times. Overall, this game is a whole lot of fun and well worth every penny spent. The creator updates relatively often and they are usually massive updates when he does. He keeps everyone informed of his goals with the game and where it is headed. It's a very good challenge and you can quit and pick it back up at any time. I personally love playing it casually while listening to some of my favorite music. It's a very relaxing, but still energetic experience.

Posted: December 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is exactly what it looks like, except for the end area. You descend 6 levels, have to pick up an orb, and re-climb them all to get out. When you pick up that orb, you have to deal with infinitely re-spawning enemies throughout the 6 levels, and all the care and patience you took in dealing with them before flies out the window. You leveled only health and made sure I had the best weapons, armor, and healing items you could have before taking the orb. It does not matter. You are swarmed with flying skulls that you cannot outrun and must fight. As you do so, Skeleton mages bombard you with magic from beyond the game's very tiny draw distance, and you die. In a game about resource managemeant and dungeon delving, rushing things leads to death, and the game forces you to do so.I do not recommend this game, and doubt it will be fixed.

								The first time I reviewed the game I didn't recommend it.  For a roguelike, it's weird I could beat it for what seemed to be my first time in an hour and a half. Posted: March 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a lot  like FTL: Short, but very addictive, insanely hard and very easy to die, but your failed runs can still help your next run, and when you think you finally made it to the end, there's a surprise finale you didn't prepare for. I really do like how the RNG traps and potions can be identified without you having to test them on yourself.  Also, poison will bring you to 1 health, but it won't kill you. Just thought you should know.

Posted: March 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a fun time sink right now.  Fought through the levels of the dungeon to get to the orb, picked it up and then all hell broke loose.  Almost made it up a floor but got knifed in the back by a skeleton.  The gold you collect can be used by your future play throughs much like Rogue Legacy.  No other persistence to your characters so far as I can tell.  Great fun though and I really recommend it.  Can't wait for the team to finish it!

Posted: March 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its Early Access so I'm sure theres lots of things that can happen, but I'm not ready to say its something I'd reccommend. Its been in production for three years and seems like it has a lot to go to make it interesting for more than a couple runthroughs. Random Dungeon Crawling Rogue-Like Game. Its missing something big and its a combination of the mechanics and lack of really any substance that wont let me enjoy it as much as I feel I could. Pros: Completely random dungeon that works well. RPG Elements. Roguelike, so you never know what you're getting or if you have any chance to succeed. Money Carries over after you die.Cons: Unrefined interface, no story, visuals are hard on eyes trying to focus between like the 16 bit characters and semi 3D environment, been in development for a long time. No real drive to play through more than a few times.Overall, i'm not sure what can be added to make it more interesting. The Dev is looking for feedback, but the biggest thing would be to fix the cons. Not sure you you do that with the short playtimes. Why are you there, what are you doing, what is driving you, who are these people, what is the reward, what do I do with all this broken and useless stuff you accumulate, are some good questions to start answering.-Comiccomwww.thecomic-community.com

This game is worth the buy it is great and has some old school touches.8.5/10 rating.

Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well-done roguelike, kind of feels like Ultima Underworld, or the dungeon sections of TESII: Daggerfall. Very fast-paced, and gives the player a good degree of control.Only downside is that it's really short. According to Steam, it took me 2.2 hours to finish, and that was with several failed attempts. However, its somewhat random nature adds replay value.

Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you remember old school fps dungeon crawlers? The ones that you have to run on dosbox now? Did you like Elder Scrolls: Daggerfall? Well then Delver is the game for you. It is pretty simple, the RPG mechanics don't go past simple stat upgrades, and equipment, which makes for thinking along the lines of: "do I want to hit really hard, or run really fast, or never die" the way to play. Combine that with rogue-like elements, and you have a very fun game. You can jump in for 10 minutes, and get a great experience. Replayability wise, the game might get dull once you've gotten the orb, however with all the different ways you can go about getting the orb, it will be worth your money. I'd highly reccomend this game to anyone that likes Elder Scrolls: Daggerfall, The Binding of Issac, or any old school fps rpg.

								So I got a 50% off coupon for this game and it was between this an Fist of Awesome. After reading into the reviews of both I figured my $4 seemed like it would be better spent on this game. Posted: November 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								--I have bought this game through the Humble Bundle store and thus my playtime here on Steam does not reflect my total playtime of the game.--This is a praiseworthy game. It's like playing a classic roguelike, the only difference being it's realtime and combat factors in your skill. Combat plays very similarly to Skyrim, and once you understand how to move and chain your attacks I think it's a very solid system.In terms of loot and magic, it's good. Once you get past the first three floors you will start finding more interesting pieces of equipment.Graphics are simple but they have a lot of work behind them. Art and lighting are very nice. Sound effects are good enough for the job.The music is better in some places than in others, but I'd say it's pretty good (especially the more atmospheric pieces down below).The game as it is is a great bargain. It's a 100% finished game as it stands. And it's good. And it's still being updated.

Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								A neat dungeon delve with a charming art style, and quite often, a bit of tension! This is a rougelike crawler that uses randomly generated dungeons to good effect, and can keep you on your toes with the ever looming chance of failure (all gold earned carries over even if you do meet your end during the adventure!). It's easy to pick up and play as the game auto saves every time you exit, and there's included mod support even in the current early access stage.Delver is shaping up to be a great game, and I can't wait to see future updates the team behind it rolls out!

Posted: October 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Reviewing this game as it is still only early access.I LOVE This game, it is freaking awesome, the old school feeling, the sense of exploration, the sights! However, I know it is still only in early access but I think there needs to be a few things added, such as a slightly larger array of weapons, Toning down the OP-ness of Enemy Magic attacks (Seriously, it will kill you almost instantly with about three hits, when melee attacks to you would usually take only about 10 hits or more) A little bit more variety of elevators and/or secrets such as Buttons to uncover a secret passage, keys to open doors, Maybe add in chests for items, SUPER (That's right, different from the normal!) Secrets, a slightly more diverse Enemy Encounters, Like, more enemies, then again, there is a good selection of enemies already but eh. I don't think maybe adding in the ability to Jump in the game would be a good idea, leave that out, it's a dungeon crawler, no one can jump while crawling. (lol) What this game is strongest in however is the difficulty, already mentioned how OP enemy magic attacks are, and that needs to be toned down ever so slightly. The sense of exploration is there and is great, the Music (Or ambient noises I guess) REALLY Immerse the player into the game, seriously, sometimes I even get shivers being creeped out, it gives you a sense of danger and fear, Afraid to turn a corner, there have been times I have been jump scared in this game because of the noises almost sounding like they bounce off the walls of the rooms. The inventory system is pretty good, you open the Inventory and the game does not pause, I like that, it gives the player a sense of panic, ESPECIALLY When you are trying to get out a potion of healing (You hope as the potions are randomized each time you play) which means you setting up your inventory bar is CRUCIAL in this game. A thing I would like to see but I kind of have gotten used to, is the ability to use the Mouse Wheel, as haing to use the 1-6 keys on my keyboard have more than once caused me to use a potion when I wanted to use my magic wand.This game is FREAKING AWESOME, if you were ever in the times of floppy disks, and played those old dungeon crawlers, and love rouge-likes, and having to fear for your life because there is perma-death in the game, this game is your new best friend!I have a couple of videos so far on the game and making a Let's Play on the game!https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5-wPdHgBWkhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=COnzuENBzds

Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Delver's art style and gameplay are reminiscent of older titles like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D, but it's most definitely a roguelike. There are a variety of weapons and items to find and use, with potions' effects changing for each playthrough. Though its replayability is not as great as I expected, Delver stays fresh and fun for many, many hours. Its random dungeon generation does provide for a unique experience for each individual delve (heh) into the deep. Overall, this is a very solid game. Heck, this thing is still in Beta.I can say with absolute certainty that I thoroughly enjoy Delver, and I cannot wait to see what the final product will look like.9.5/10

Posted: June 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is one of the best First Person pixel games ive seen in a long time. When I first started playing the game I thought of it as tedious and unoriginal. Boy was I wrong, it only seems like alot of other games untill you get further in the dungeons. I had my heart skip a beat at every corner in the sewers. The way that a spider from across the map can echo deep into another part of the cave is spinetingleing. And since once your charecter dies you have to start over you can become legitamently scared for your pixelated life. A few problems I have had though are that the hardest enemy in the game can be bats. They take a lot more hits then they should be able to and have drivin me insane in the deeper levels. This game is glorious and would benefit greatly from Co-Op Multiplayer. But even as a single player game this is a must buy.

Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a fantastic rendition of a traditional Roguelike! The art style is beautiful, the combat is fun, and the Roguelike elements are pure and well implemented. At the time of this writing, Delver is an Early Access title. I do hope that the developer expands upon the existing game, although the current build is a fairly solid Roguelike. I think it would be nice for there to be more variety in the environments and enemies as you decend through each level of the dungeon.As a lifelong fan of Roguelikes, I can safely say that Delver is a great example of the genre. I have been following the development of this game since it was first announced and before it made its way to Steam. I am quite happy with how it has eveolved over time. I look forward to seeing what future updates bring to this game.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								In my own opinion (please don't hate me internets) this is one of the best roguelike games out there.  The art style is charming, the music is catchy, and the environments keep the dungeon from getting to stale and repetitive.  I've been playing this game since it was in the alpha stages before it was even on Steam, and every time an update is released, it introduces new and exciting features to the game.  One of the strongest features though is the balance between difficulty, length, and permadeath.  The game isn't tremendously long, but it is quite challenging.  This is fantastic because when you win it feels like an accomplishment, but if you die it isn't a crippling blow as you were probably only 3-6 floors down.  Another 20 or 30 minutes and you could potentially get there again.  This game is a hidden gem of the indie developer scene and I sincerely hope it receives the recognition it deserves.

Posted: November 17, 2015
Early Access Review
Description   Delver is a first-person dungeon-crawling RPG. Its graphics are very sharp and appealing. When you die, you have to start the game over again. Combat is interesting, but, at some times, extremely repetitive. The potions give random effects determined at the starting generation of a new game. Enemies are cool and have slightly varied ways of combat. You can level up and use points to upgrade certain skills, and weapons vary a fair amount.Should I buy it?   Yes. It's a great game, and new content is confirmed to come, but the game get's boring after five or so hours of total gameplay. You can easily mod the game with new weapons, armor, dungeon rooms, enemies, meshes, items - pretty much everything! The community is very small, and I hope it grows more soon.Rating   I'll give Delver an 8/10.It's great for short, 45 minute bursts of gameplay, but any longer can often get boring. A few mods are being developed, one of which is a desert crypt dungeon mod which has an early version you can play. I really hope the developer, pardon me forgetting his name, adds more content soon, seeing as the game, once you beat it, gets boring after a while.

Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! It reminds so much of Pixel Dungeon, except it's first person which makes it so cool! I love how simple the mechanics are, and especially how the food works. I also love the fact that you don't know what potions do until you drink them, and that traps do random things. I wouldn't say it's worth the $8 at the moment, but I am really glad that I bought it because it has so much potential to be even better.Some things I would recommend would be:- Option to sell items at the shops (hate to carry around 2nd best gear and have to leave it lying around)- Smaller minimap marker (the current arrow is way too big)- Mouse wheel to scroll through belt (using the numbers takes your hand off of WASD, which can get you killed since you can't move then)- Overworld map with multiple towns (then you can have a choice between what dungeons you want to go into, with each town having a dungeon that leans towards a different theme, like caves, bandits, etc.)- Jumping Maybe (the girl with the staff can jump, why can't I?)- COOP!!!! (this game would be awesome with a friend! although, I don't really know how you would pull that off...)These are just suggestions and I think the game could be even more amazing with them implemented (well, mostly the mouse scroll, minimap, and selling).

Early Access Review
								I must say this is a fine little game. Everything looks nice, the mechanics are well done, and it is fun to play.That being said I am running this game on Linux Mint and because the game is made with Java, it automatically works for Linux.  Well.. it kind of works.I am having a weird glitch/bug happen when I level up.  During the game play, upon leveling, I am unable to use my mouse on the menu where you upgrade your players stats. Instead the mouse is invisible and the characters camera still moves.  My most recent playthrough was great, until I level. I made it to cave 2 and when I leveled, I was unable to upgrade my stats and click done. Because of this, I had to quit the game.I would be happy to change this review, when this bug is fixed.  Honestly, I love the game, but this bug is very annoying.

Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								-Such a Awsome game!There are a few basic enimie types that are reskined threw out the game and given more damage and at times different abilities such as poison, or the ability to lung. The game offers a level of persistence in the ability to keep ones gold after loosing a game, which really adds to urge to play inorder to get better loot on your journey. The areas that you'll find look wonderful, and i found myself most at awe during the ice levels that seemed to demand every ounce of my attention. The combat is easy to learn and can get really intense when you've been starved for resources and somehow manage to defeat that one really hard enemy within an inch of your own life.  The only think that draws away from the game for me is the music, something about the sounds of the guitar are just not to my liking, however thats just in my opinion and im sure many of you will find it to be just your type of music for such a game.
