Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								OH man.  OH ok.  I think I am just broken in a way that makes me love this game a whole lot,  First thing, any random dungeon game gets my attention.   Second, any first person dungeoneering thing gets my attention.   So this is both and it's really good.  The art style is like some you have seen before but it is sweet.  Sweet in a way that evokes a certian feeling that other games that use a similar graphical tone really can't do very well.   Not sure how many folks are involved here, I know one might or might not be named Chad, but whoever does the art loves this game.  The fidelity of such would allow for one person to do a whole lot of work to enter in their own perfect vision of the art presentation for the game, and that is great.  By accident or by design it feels to me like the dungeon and the caves (the two locales I have seen so far) are part of cohesive whole that I really like.  The monsters and the npc enemies have good personality, and the sound assets created/selected for them fit very well.  Details regarding the movement of the character and his/her weapons lend the whole game a satisfying weight that just really scratches things that I  like to get scratched.  Combat has a dance like quailty that really changes based on the monster/enemy encountered.   After that it requires a bit of thinking that is easy to do usually but has lots of fun twists invovling number of enemies/elevations/weapons owned or currently using...  meaning that you will be rolling out hard one moment only to have yourself chased down into hard corners, stomping onto pressure plates and getting killed by traps you navigaed deftly only a minute before. Delver is really worth your time and money, and there should be more games like it.  Here's hoping that Chad and whoever make a mint of dollars and buy huge houses.

Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought the game because it looked like fun and because I like Rogue-like games, but hell was I surprised how fun it is. Its really addicting and defenetly worth its price. It has awesome music, an easy game concept, it has smooth and simple controlls and an incredibly well created atmosphere. In addition to that it has a good replay value, because it doesnt really get you angry when you die. And also it has a touch of "looting and leveling" combined with the desire of exploring these random generated floors. And its simple graphics have a charm because they are mixed with modern shading- and ligh- effects. And in some areas like the sewer(3rd screenshot) it features this fog which I personally like because it just creates a really nice atmosphere. The atmosphere of the game feels right, the gameplay feels right, and so does the whole game. It sadly doesnt have much of a story, but thats pretty normal for rogue-like games.- Sadly the game still has a few bugs, for example: you can get stuck in certain areas(like the sewer), but you can just go in the folder of the savestates and then change your x,y and z coordinates with an editor.(-> Also the game has lots of mods etc, and it is very easy to mod the game, because its all open source(the game also has a level editor))So in conclusion I can say that the game itself is alot of fun and that it is a fair game with nice gameplay, a replay value and a great atmosphere. You might stumble upon some bugs, but its an early access game and these bugs are usually fixably by the player him-/her-self, so that isnt much of a negativ thing. In my opinion the game is a really well made indie/rogue-like game which I had much fun with. But in the end it is up to YOU if you are going to purchase it or not,either way, have a nice day!

Posted: February 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								   Besides "Retro", I really think that the best way to describe this game is by looking at the Tags for it. This is a combination(of Tags) that has been used over and over again throughout the evolution of game-making. So, calling it Retro doesn't mean anything, it's a system that is still being used by many game-designers.    Anyway, this game does for me what something that most other dungeon crawler-esque games simply cannot do. And that is, the RPG element of complete item and body management. It's not just a game of, "Pick this item up and it is now in your use forever!", or "Collected item under 'X' Tab. Now, when you press 'X', this item will show up under 1 of the 4 Available Slots in the 'X' Item Slot for Weapons." This game actually has items that have Durabilities/Charges, and when you use these items until thier usable lifespan, they simply become useless.    You have an inventory yes, but it isn't huge, and you are going to need to carry backups for strong Spell Wands or gear. The "flavor" of this game is quite nice, and the artstyle makes it almost feel loving and comfortable. The music is spot on, the sound effects are pretty cool, and the game flows very smoothly. Yea, it has its' flaws. But what in the gaming world doesn't these days. But, I feel that I can easily take the good with the bad on this one, because I feel that the good vastly outweighs the bad in this title. I will not mention the negative views I have for the game, because I feel that most, if not all in some sense, of my negatives for this game are subjective and really hold no real chance of being considered game altering in any way good of bad.    Alrighty then, that was a bit of a rant. I really like this game, and would happily give it a 7/10. I am writing this review during Early Access of the title, and cannot give any higher of a grade until a full release is available to play. I recommend you at least watch some gameplay footage of this somewhere. It's a delight to just exist in the world through the voice of someone else playing in it. You are a quiet observer overseeing the events of an adventurer delving deep underground in search of only the gods may know what. (I've actually never completed the first level. That stuff is hard yo!) But then I hope that you are intrigued enough to delve into the experience first-hand and give it a go for yourself. Dueces!!!

Posted: July 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								let me just say this is a great game for a Beta and worth $8, but it does have some problems, for example there is no jump button, i understand that this is a dungeon crawler, there are some glitches where you can fall into a hole with no way out, and the easiest way to get out is by jumping, which ou cant do, i experienced this problem multiple times in my first 2.5 hours played. but glitches aside this is a great game, it has every thing a dungeon crawler should and the gameplay feels like a pixilated Skyrim, which is good, its got plenty of loot, and with randomly generated dungeons this makes the experience highly replayable. I would highly recommend this game to any RPG fan.

Posted: October 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								Graphics - 5/5The graphics of this game are amazingly well put together,to give you a fresh retro feel.Audio - 5/5The music plays a big part in the atmosphere in Delver,Without it, this game just doesn't feel the same.Gameplay - 4/5The gameplay is insanely good and highly addictive,with a nice twist that even got my adrenaline pumping for a while.I give this game a 4.7 out of 5, had the game been longer,and contained more content, then I'd give it a 5.-An amazing, yet short dungeon crawler game.This game is best played on it's first run,as the game only gets easier and easier each time you play it.The main problem is that your character keeps the gold you've earned when you die,and with this gold, you can buy skillpoints for your newly created character back in town.This of course, makes the game way too easy.The game also comes with a dungeon editor,so you can create and release your own dungeons.

Posted: January 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I must say this is a fine little game. Everything looks nice, the mechanics are well done, and it is fun to play.That being said I am running this game on Linux Mint and because the game is made with Java, it automatically works for Linux.  Well.. it kind of works.I am having a weird glitch/bug happen when I level up.  During the game play, upon leveling, I am unable to use my mouse on the menu where you upgrade your players stats. Instead the mouse is invisible and the characters camera still moves.  My most recent playthrough was great, until I level. I made it to cave 2 and when I leveled, I was unable to upgrade my stats and click done. Because of this, I had to quit the game.I would be happy to change this review, when this bug is fixed.  Honestly, I love the game, but this bug is very annoying.

Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I held of buying this for quite a while because I just wasn't sure.  STUPID move.  I enjoy this game WAY more than I expected.  I'd even say they could have charged more and I'd still be happy with it.  Such great fun to give in and see how long you last.  Since the dungeons are procedurally generated you never get the same thing.  I'm still finding new themed rooms and areas.Only bad thing is I have a huge urge to collect all the loot I find and there really doesn't seem to be a point to do that.  Just keep what's good and throw the old stuff on the ground, there is no selling.  I also wish you could see your character but again in a rogue type there really isn't a point to spend time with character creation.  If you die quickly you wasted all that time.  Being an RPG I just have that desire.It's only a few bucks.  Just buy it already.

Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Been playing this rather alot since I bought it a couple of days ago (I have 4 kids, time is precious :) ).The first thing that made me go all nostalgic is the way that this is so similiar to Ultima Underworld. How many people can remember playing that?  It's likeness is remarkable and with this in mind when I started I have thoroughly enjoyed it.How awesome are those graphics!  I spotted a mod available that changes the textures to HD but I think that it would take away from the feel of the game.  Weapons are good and the generated layouts are excellent, a little more food dotted about wouldn't go amiss especially passed Cave 2 :)I wasn't sure what the point of the gold was until I found a shop further in the levels, but the ones outside confused me until I realised that when you died, whatever gold you collected comes with you :)  happy days, not all for nought :)Excellent game, well done and keep up the good work (I'm going to have a look at the level editor now)

Posted: April 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is still in early access, but even so it's more than playable. It took me 4 hours and around 5 tries to beat this game.It's a fairly simple roguelike with real time combat. You'll probably find a playstyle you like, as each of the half dozen or so weapons to choose from have different attributes. Personally I liked using a dagger with points put into agility, because later in the game there are a lot of wizards that are hard to beat unless you can interrupt their spellcasting.The artstyle is executed very well, and the atmosphere is excellent, especially in the cave levels.Definitely pick this up on sale, or for the full price when it's out of beta.

Posted: March 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Excellent first-person, rogue-like, not too pixelated-pixelated, dungeon explorer. I love the music and how some enemies seem to come out of  nowhere. This game is great if you like an fps/rpg/rogue-like, minimalist game and don't easily get nausiated from erratic user-mouse movement (because that's kinda my style). It's less pixelated than Home so it doesn't mess with my vision once I look away from my screen. Although when enemies get right in front of your face they get a little distorted but I'm sure that was intended by the developers and adds a nice flavor to the gameplay. Overall, super fun. One of the best early access games I've purchased regardless of the fact that I bought it on sale. There has been a little bit of clipping through walls (throwing items directly into a wall at about a 30 degree angle and hallways that loop around) but it's in parts that I can't tell if it was intentional or not so this is not a negative comment, more so a random add-on to my review.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								In my own opinion (please don't hate me internets) this is one of the best roguelike games out there.  The art style is charming, the music is catchy, and the environments keep the dungeon from getting to stale and repetitive.  I've been playing this game since it was in the alpha stages before it was even on Steam, and every time an update is released, it introduces new and exciting features to the game.  One of the strongest features though is the balance between difficulty, length, and permadeath.  The game isn't tremendously long, but it is quite challenging.  This is fantastic because when you win it feels like an accomplishment, but if you die it isn't a crippling blow as you were probably only 3-6 floors down.  Another 20 or 30 minutes and you could potentially get there again.  This game is a hidden gem of the indie developer scene and I sincerely hope it receives the recognition it deserves.

Early Access Review
								It might not look like it from screenshots, but this humble game oozes polish in almost every respect. The animations, for example, are unbelievably slick, and they get across a real sense of responsiveness and weapon impact. Posted: May 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								(First of all, in the time that this was written, the game had just received an update after nearly a year, this is because one of the developers had a baby and they had to pause in the development. So if you read any more negative reviews that were made before or around the time this review was made, if they mention anything about the developers not updating, this is why.)Delver is a simple roguelike dungeon crawler that is, I believe, heavily influenced by games like DOOM and Zelda.The objective of the game is to enter a procedurally generated dungeon (Different every time) that consists of several floors with different themes, get the treasure, and return to the surface safely.I don't want to spoil to much, because Delver, I think, is supposed to give you a feeling of wonder, suspense, and the unknown. And, despite being very simple, I feel it somehow does this very well, even after playing the game multiple times. Which I think is why I love it so much. The game is somewhat difficult, maybe even unfair at times, but hey, why would the enemy make it fair in the first place?And also, that is part of the mystery, sometimes, dungeons are full of loot and as you make your way down, you will eventually become nearly invincible, other times, you really have to just make do what you have, and sometimes the traps and the general layout of the dungeon is a real pain in the butt. so, basically, the games difficulty is different EVERY TIME. Which, personally, I think is brilliant. But of course, I highly doubt anyone will be having any competitions with this for $10,000 anytime soon. Which is OK.I cannot express the feeling of winning this, especially for the first time. It makes my day even more than cookies do.Which is saying a lot. I challenge you to beat Delver, if you dare. But remember, it was hidden away for a reason.Edit: Some screenshots I took:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765355710http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765356107http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=765355965

Posted: October 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Delver is one of the few dungeon crawlers that I love. This game has tons of potential to become an amazing dungeon crawler game and with the developer coming back after his first kid i'm hoping we can see more from the developer. In broad terms the game revolves around you delving into a dungeon to retrieve the yithidian orb. Along the way you will pass through different levels/stages all being unique to each other such as sewers/temple etc. All of these levels have different mobs and level design so you wont feel that your facing the same thing over and over(although some of the enemies AI are similar). Also the loot from going into the dungeon is unique enough in its state, with different armor/weapons/ring each with different attributes. The game is like medium difficulty but can be difficult and put a fire under your♥♥♥♥♥at some points. Whenever you die you lose all your items and character progress, but along your playthrough you can collect gold, which can be used to buy items to help your future playthroughs. Combat is basic, with essentialy a charged attack for melee and wands, and shooting your bow and arrow. Although the combat is basic it's satisfying enough to enjoy and play the game over and over again, considering its RNG of level layout and armor. Whenever you level up you are able to choose from a pool of attributes, attack, speed, health etc. The attributes are really basic and some attributes are really underpowered, like defense or magic. The hit box for the enemies are kinda weird, but not annoying to where it becomes a major problem. Also I feel that for a dungeon crawler with getting loot and wanting the player to play again and again, I think it shouldnt make you lose all your items once you beat the game. Instead of losing your items it should let you keep your items, but ramp up the difficulty of mobs and mabye more levels. This would give the game more replay value and make the player feel more "rewarding" instead of just saying congrats you beat the game! and restart your character.The mechanics for the game are basic but fun, it gives you the feel of an actual dungeon crawler, searching for loot and randomized levels. However, I feel the game lacks because it is very basic in some areas(i know its in early access). Only having a charged attack and simple character sheets leaves a lot of room for improvments and gear that can be more unique. The progress of the game has been very slow recently(and I know the developer just had a baby) but hopefully we can see some progress as I've seen the developer working on it on his twitch stream. Delver is one of those games that you come back to every once and awhile and feels new when you do come back to it, and I hope to see this game released in the future because I see potential for Delver becoming an amazing game.

Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Right off the bat-- if you don't like pixel graphics, rogue-like, and incomplete games than pass this one by. If you're a fan of all of these than PURCHASE NOW! My good buddy 'rragnaar' turned me on to Delver, a dungeon crawl of epic potential, and I've become fascinated with it ever since.In Delver, you play as... the delver, a neuterd class that you build as you descend the 'catacombs', searching for an orb to bring back to basecamp. Along the way, you encounter bats, bugs, blue ogre men, skeletal mages, spike traps, etc-- that slows you down. When I say neutered class, I mean you begin as a basic everyclass and expand on the various skills allowed with every level you make-- you know, an RPG if you will ; )You can technically build a warrior, mage, or rogue/ranger, whith dropped armor and weapons of diffferent craft and enchantments to help further define your 'class'. For the record, there is no class persay, but after 12 hours of playing and only beating it once, I knew that the only way to beat it was focus on dumping skill points into health, keep my speed as fast as delver would allow me, and use the dagger and bow. It's a basic rogue build. This build system is where I became fascinated with the game. This build system has incredible potential for players to compare and contrast game winning builds, like the Diablo series. But... the game has yet to be finished.Don't let that stop you from buying it. The price is not bad for the hours you could put into it. I would say that I will probably stop playing after twenty hours, unless another update arrives within the near future. Pick this up.7/11

Posted: November 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Delver is a neat little rogue-like game that has a lot of potential.PROS:++ The 2d artstyle mixed with the first person perspective give it a fun look+ Environments are pretty and neat+ little notes along the way give bits of different stories to the history of the placeNeutral: Randomized stat progression as you level up No real tutorial/mechanics not explained  Still plenty of bugs (out of place textures, mobs floating into the ceiling but still able to hit you)CONS:- - Adds nothing new to the genre. Aside from the artstyle, it's the same as any other roguelike you can play- A lot of useless items- cannot sell items- HEAVY on the random side. about 80/20 luck/skill ratio to getting through the game.All in all it's a fun re-hash of rogue mechanics that is pretty and can keep you entertained for a bit. Has a lot of promise to be very fun, I just feel like it's missing something to make it really stand out.

Posted: April 8
Early Access Review
								This is a fun, addicting game. I've barely had it for a day and I'm already hooked on it. There's plenty to explore, collect, loot, kill, and just look at. Given that this game is in Beta I believe, I'm expecting much more in the future. The pixelated art style is charming and adds a certain quality that makes it kind of light hearted and not too serious. That's also a good way to describe the game as well, since this game is pretty easy as far as Roguelikes go. The combat isn't anything special, but it's balanced and deep enough to keep it interesting while playing. I never found it to be tedious, and it was fun timing and landing charged attacks. The menus are a bit confusing though. Nothing really goes in depth in explaining them and I'm still not sure if I've got it all figured out. The default button for your inventory is "I" which is a bit out of the way and inconvenient considering that the main form of movement is WSAD. If there's more movement options or a way to change the controls, I am unaware of those at this time. Another problem I had with the menus was using items. There's no indication of what button does what, nor is there any explanation as to what anything does. I had a potion in my hot bar so I could drink it. Instead, I threw it on the ground, and it exploded. It took me a minute to realize that to use some items, you had to be in your inventory, which can be a hindrance in tense moments of battle where you need something from your inventory and quickly. There's definitely room for improvements to menu functionality and more, even if small and brief, tutorials. A note saying "Drink potions from your inventory and put them on your belt to throw them!" would be just fine. Other than those, this game is pretty solid and simple, and has room to expand upon in the future. If you're looking for your next short addiction (or maybe even a long one) this is a good game to look into.

								Love the art style. I love this game so far but I think it feels a bit too plain and easy (not your normal rogue like). I know it's early access but there needs a variety of different enemies or different stats of enemies (say slimes... there should be fire, lava, water, etc slimes) I find myself running around and easily killing enemies. I should be afraid of the unknown not confident.And the traps are soooo soooo soooo obvious and visible. You can avoid it easily unless it's down a 1 block path. I think removing the huge plate and making it almost the same as the floor but different colour will make me not want to run around and be careful were I go.You can play all styles heavy warrior, archer, mage (no cast spells only wands I think. I haven't gotten far yet). The only enemies I encountered so far and I really hate that makes this game a bit challenging are those floating eyes of eyes that shoot burning balls. So op. I only find like 1-2 enemies each room. And that I can easily kill (again I haven't reached that far. I only reached ruins). If enemies were more difficult and more in numbers (could be a mod) I would love this game more.One last thing. All weapons and armors rings necklaces (foods?) Are all identified. Except for potions... I like the sense of having to be careful with everything you find and needing a scroll of identification to make sure the items are safe. (Cursed unfurled blessed etc). It made the game more challenging and a sense of wanting to beat the game. (I'm talking about nethack the origin of rogue likes ). So far I would recommend the game. I'm looking forward to the final product and hope they change it to the way I think it should be (or mods).

Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is fun and intuitive but I have to say I docked points for finding a trap in a hallway I couldn't avoid in any way; The game doesn't allow you to jump and the way the tile was positioned it wouldn't let me pass without walking over the plate. Having to budget health for gauranteed damage from traps in a roguelike is like trying to pay your mortgage payment with dryer lint. You just don't have the ability to do that. However, I will be willing to play the game some more if I discover that was a very uncommon situation; IE, up until the point I encounter that problem again. If you enjoy roguelikes and you really liked the Might & Magic 1st person adventure games, you'll enjoy Delver.Update (Spoiler Warning): It is possible to deal with most traps without stepping on them even if they are between you and the path you need to go down, but there are still areas and configurations where they will always hit you, even if you try to disable them. Still holding my thumb up but sequels will need some tweaking.

								This game is extremely simplistic, and very addictive. It prides itself on its Roguelike qualities while pushing you through the depths of caves, dungeons, and chamber after chamber of increasingly difficult baddies that you have the option of slaying with a plethora of weapon pick-ups -- everything from wands to enchanted daggers and armors --  that increase in power as you do. I couldn't say enough about how much fun I've had in the randomly generated world of underground wonders here in the land of Delver. Pick it up, boot it up, and you'll have a new experience every single time. The best part is that it's still in Beta!Update: I first started playing Delver online as a flash game and loved its simplicity, it has come a long way and I'm genuinely proud of the work this guy has done on a basic dugeon-crawling roguelike. It's got life to it, and it's something special...still in beta after 4 years? Why the hell not. You earned it.

If enemies were more difficult and more in numbers (could be a mod) I would love this game more.One last thing. All weapons and armors rings necklaces (foods?) Are all identified. Except for potions... I like the sense of having to be careful with everything you find and needing a scroll of identification to make sure the items are safe. (Cursed unfurled blessed etc). It made the game more challenging and a sense of wanting to beat the game. (I'm talking about nethack the origin of rogue likes ). So far I would recommend the game. I'm looking forward to the final product and hope they change it to the way I think it should be (or mods).

								Delver unlike most first person rougelikes is able to captivate in a retro pixel art style without seeming like its pawing at the pants of the crowd, like some sort of nostalgia♥♥♥♥♥kitty.while the game does have some issues such as the problem where the exit of the floor is placed on the otherside of a room that the player is almost completely unable to get past unless they find a random item drop, which had for obvious reasons infuriated me to no end though I imagine it will be patched out fairly soon.Ultimately if your a fan of the dungeon crawler experience then I must recomend Delver to you for its unique mechanics enjoyable gameplay and brilliant concept, a real treat in the independant games market.

Posted: September 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is extremely simplistic, and very addictive. It prides itself on its Roguelike qualities while pushing you through the depths of caves, dungeons, and chamber after chamber of increasingly difficult baddies that you have the option of slaying with a plethora of weapon pick-ups -- everything from wands to enchanted daggers and armors --  that increase in power as you do. I couldn't say enough about how much fun I've had in the randomly generated world of underground wonders here in the land of Delver. Pick it up, boot it up, and you'll have a new experience every single time. The best part is that it's still in Beta!Update: I first started playing Delver online as a flash game and loved its simplicity, it has come a long way and I'm genuinely proud of the work this guy has done on a basic dugeon-crawling roguelike. It's got life to it, and it's something special...still in beta after 4 years? Why the hell not. You earned it.
